TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Technical and Further Education Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned teachers and students working and studying in TAFE colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We assert that TAFE, with over 1 million students, requires greatly improved resources if it is to continue to train Australia's skilled workforce effectively.

2. We call upon the Commonwealth Government to provide greatly increased funds to ensure that TAFE is accessible to all Australians, unlike the present time when thousands of people are turned away from TAFE colleges each year.

3. We urge the Commonwealth Government to equip TAFE workshops with the advanced technology used in modern Australian industries, and to expand TAFE's capital works program so that sufficient quality accommodation is available for TAFE teachers and students.
4. We ask that the Commonwealth Government greatly increase TAFE's recurrent expenditure, so that TAFE can respond quickly and flexibly to industry, Government and community demands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ARCHER; BAUME; HARRADINE; RAE; RICHARDSON; ROBERTSON; TATE; WATSON
PETITION.TITLE: Customs Regulations: Importation of Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That Regulations and an Ordinance before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulation and the Customs (Cinematograph and Films) Regulations and supersedes the ACT Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth Law-
The power to prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications including those associated with blasphemy;
The power to require videos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board before release from Customs.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure:
That the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
That the Censors more appropriately reflect reasonable and responsible community attitudes;
That further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation;
That, because of the importance of this issue to the whole community a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 47 citizens), Peter Baume (from 18 citizens), Harradine (from 134 citizens), Peter Rae (from 18 citizens), Richardson (from 36 citizens) , Robertson (from 24 citizens), Tate (from 50 citizens) and Watson (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Parliamentary Leadership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1. We deplore recent moves by the Government to grant equal travelling allowances to the de facto partners of Parliamentarians as are currently enjoyed by spouses.
2. We further believe that such action belittles the institution of marriage and harms the status of the family unit in Australia.
3. We believe parliamentarians should offer leadership in moral as well as political affairs, and that the above recent action of the Government has contributed to the undermining of this principle.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Income Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. the Hawke Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent, and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements; and
2. the Government's proposed assets test legislation is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. scrap its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad inquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter; and
3. following the report of such a wide enquiry institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Welfare Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That there is grave cause for concern in the Australian community at the continuing sensationalist media and political campaign directed against the humanitarian and socially just effects of the Welfare State (most recently exemplified by the frontpage article 'One in 4 get Welfare Hand' in the Melbourne Herald of Monday, 3rd October 1983).

That, whilst enlarging public awareness of the critical social problems facing our community, such articles tend to paint the victims of our social system as worthless parasites living off the work force.

1. We believe that the 635,000 persons receiving unemployment benefits at the end of June 1983 deserve full support from the Commonwealth, and that the 85,104 persons receiving sickness and special benefits deserve society's sympathy rather than castigation.

2. We also believe that the 2,011,542 persons receiving age, invalid, wife and widow pensions, supporting parent benefits and sheltered employment allowances at the end of June 1983 deserve help from the Commonwealth.

3. We affirm that it is the time-honoured and moral right of Australians to receive assistance in times of distress and hardship, and we remind the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia of its profound responsibility to safeguard and enhance the dignity and well-being of its citizens.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

Although many occurrences of sexual harrassment in the workforce have been reported to various State government authorities, such as the Victorian Commission for Equal Opportunity, the real incidence of sexual intimidation in employment will not be known, or countered, until a national policy towards sexual harrassment is determined and implemented.
We therefore submit that:

1. The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation be commissioned to conduct a nation-wide study of discrimination based on sex, both in the private sector and the Public Service, with a view to advising the Government on the development of national policy.
2. The major priority of such a study should be to determine a legally- enforceable definition of sexual harrassment.

3. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations should bring forward in Parliament legislation, arising from such a study, to outlaw discrimination and intimidation in employment based on sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of three Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in view of the serious and chronic level of unemployment in Australia, the Senate is of the opinion that the Federal Government should, as a matter of urgency, legislate for optional early retirement of workers on the following bases:
(1) An employer would be permitted to release an employee up to two years earlier than the normal retirement age and the full age pension would be paid, provided that-
(a) the person thus retired was replaced by a person at present unemployed; and
(b) the retiree was willing to be so retired.

(2) Retirement at three years early would be available where it could be demonstrated that the cost of paying the pension to the retiree would be less than the cost of unemployment benefits to the person who would replace the retiree.

(3) The legislation to take into account the experiences of other countries, such as West Germany, the Scandinavian countries and other European countries, where similar procedures are already working satisfactorily and have provided many thousands of jobs.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to the speech that he made to the Vietnam Veterans Association in Sydney on Saturday and his criticism of suggestions that the Budget deficit should be of the order of $5 billion in 1984-85. Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister, who said in Perth on 19 April: 'We will significantly reduce the deficit in this year's Budget'? If so, what level of deficit would be acceptable to the Minister? Did he urge the Vietnam veterans to campaign for extra spending? If so, does he believe that he can accommodate increased benefits by cutting other areas of this Department's expenditure?

—It is not for me to determine-although I hope I will be part of the process that will determine it-the level of the deficit. Certainly if there is to be a reduction in the deficit, it will not be at the expense of my Department. As I pointed out at the Vietnam Veterans Congress, $3 billion, which is the greatest proportion of my Budget allocation each year, is of a non- discretionary nature-that is to say, if veterans have an entitlement of a claim for disability and it is in accordance with the Repatriation Acts, the Government is obliged to pay such benefits. As there is a growth factor in every sector of my Department, there is no possibility of any savings being effected as far as this or any other Budget is concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the the Acting Minister for Health. Has he seen the Australian Medical Association pamphlet seeking contributions to the AMA freedom fund? Is the AMA both insulting many doctors and obtaining funds under false pretences, since most of the so-called freedoms listed are not under attack, even if one allows for the emotionally and politically worded tone of the appeal? How many of the freedoms are under threat? Does the AMA mention its opposition to medical practitioners informing patients of such matters as their fees and whether or not they bulk bill, which severely restricts the freedom of some of its members and of patients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have had drawn to my attention the appeal by the Australian Medical Association to doctors throughout Australia asking doctors each to pledge at least $200 immediately and to guarantee to pledge further funds later to enable the AMA to defend the freedoms that it sees as important in the health system against attacks by governments or anyone else that it sees is going to attack these freedoms. The sorts of freedom listed are: The free and unrestricted choice of the doctor by the patient and likewise of the patient by the doctor, so that both parties retain their individuality and sense of responsibility, and no barrier is separating the patient from free choice of specialist or doctor. I point out to the honourable senator that, under the existing health system, those freedoms are not under attack, except to the extent that medical practitioners, in particular those in public hospitals, are against patients' capacity, other than fee paying patients, to make their choice of doctors in those hospitals.

ANSWER.PARA: The AMA also suggests that under attack are the freedom of a doctor to choose the type and locality of his practice; the freedom and opportunity to practice on a fee for service basis without threat of coercion or compulsion-I defy any member of the medical profession to demonstrate where either of those freedoms is under attack; the freedom to preserve professional secrecy in the high standard of medical ethics; the freedom of doctors to treat their patients in hospital within the limits of their training, experience and demonstrated competence; and the freedom to prescribe what is best for the patient. Those freedoms are not under attack by this Government or the existing health insurance scheme. To suggest that the Federal Council of the Australian Medical Association should be able to receive the sums of money suggested and to use them at its discretion for political purposes is, as Senator Coates says, an insult to the intelligence of the doctors and of the electorate of this country.

It is significant, as Senator Coates says, that among the freedoms not listed are the freedoms of a doctor to advertise just what he charges or the freedom of a doctor to advertise whether or not he bulk bills. The lack of this freedom inhibits the freedom of choice of many patients in this country to determine, before they are treated, what they will be charged and how they will be charged. That is an important freedom. Those members of the medical profession who are indulging in this activity should remember that freedom goes both ways-it applies to the patients as well as the doctors. I expect that these extravagant requests from the Federal Council of the AMA will not receive much support from most members of the medical profession.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to the document released by the Australian Mining Industry Council on Friday concerning the mining and export of Australia's uranium deposits for peaceful purposes in the generation of electricity. I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the study's finding:

QUESTION.PARA: Advanced negotiations by owners/operators of existing and potential uranium mines have shown clearly the existence of market opportunities for their exports .
I ask whether he further agrees:
The state of the spot market is not properly representative of the prospects for term contract sales or prices.

How confident is the Minister of persuading the Australian Labor Party National Conference in July to adopt a policy which will enable Australians to benefit from the almost 5,000 direct jobs and the thousands of millions of dollars in investment and export earnings which AMIC says will flow from the development of existing and potential uranium mines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —A copy of the document arrived in my office this morning. I have not had a chance to read it or even open it, nor have I had a chance yet to read the summary which the Department has done and which was dropped on my desk about a quarter of an hour ago. So, I cannot respond in any detail because I am just not sure what is in that document. In particular, I am not sure of the context in which the reference to the market opportunity that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle mentioned was made, in particular whether it is a market opportunity three years hence or a market opportunity perceived in the early or late 1990s. I will consider making a definitive response at some later stage if the Opposition so wishes. But I just have not had time at this stage to give that sort of response, obviously, since I have not read it.

ANSWER.PARA: I will make one more comment on the spot market. It is self-evidently correct that the price available on the spot market at any time is not a particularly reliable indicator of the price that may be available, particularly, as is the case with uranium, when we are looking at supply contracts which extend up to 10 years with a total delivery period of up to 15 years after the contract has been signed. Such contracts are not uncommon in uranium supply. Therefore, with lead times of 10 to 15 years spot market prices for uranium are more unreliable than for most other metals. However, the Opposition does not always seem to have been particularly deterred by that fact because I remember that about six months ago, when the spot market price was of the order of $23 a pound, someone in the Opposition cited that fact as evidence that there was a clear hardening of the market. The last time I looked the price was $17 something a pound, but that has not been cited as a clear weakening of the market. I think the correct way to view it is to be consistent and to recognise that the spot market price, even with significant variations such as those between $23 and $17 a pound, is not a particularly reliable indicator of the prices that might actually be obtained from the commercial market 10 or 15 years hence, which is really the most relevant period which ought to be considered, for purely commercial reasons, by those who may be contemplating establishing new mines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations advise the Senate whether the Koorie community youth support scheme research project into the needs of young unemployed Aboriginals has been completed? However I do know, because I was deputising for Senator Button at the Estimates Committee A meeting last Friday, that a number of questions regarding Aboriginal employment and other employment initiatives were asked and that those questions also were taken on notice and replies to them will be provided. —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy a question about Maralinga and indicate, according to my usual custom, that he has had notice of it for the last hour and a half. Is it true that the Government has a document concerning the Maralinga tests which indicates that 13 atomic tests took place at Maralinga during the period from 1 January 1960 to 31 December 1963, that eight of those atomic tests involved weapons containing plutonium and four contained uranium and thorium, that one test contained cobalt 60 and uranium, and that, in tests on casings, casings were fractured and then dropped and exploded to test radioactive fallout in the event of a plane crash? Why is the Government reluctant to expose publicly all the information it has about the Maralinga atomic tests? I further ask: Has the Government received advice from either the Department of Foreign Affairs or the Department of Defence that the British Government must not be offended at any cost? If not, why is the Government perpetuating what is rapidly appearing to be a cover-up on this issue ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the last phrase-the suggestion of a cover-up-was particularly ill-chosen. The first part of the question that Senator Chipp asked was about whether 13 atomic tests-I will say a bit more about what may be defined as an atomic test-did take place at Maralinga during the period from the beginning of 1960 to the end of 1963. Whether the Government has a document which shows they were, I think, they are the terms in which the question was put . The Government does have a document that shows that 13 tests were conducted in that period. The public also has had that document for about five years, so I think the reference to a cover-up in respect of that is particularly inopportune .

ANSWER.PARA: As to whether they were atomic tests, they were not nuclear explosions. In at least some of those tests-I am not sure of the precise number and therefore I cannot respond to Senator Chipp's precise reference to eight allegedly containing plutonium and four containing uranium and thorium-uranium and plutonium, but I am not sure about thorium, were associated with the explosions which took place, were adjacent to the other explosive material, but the explosive material itself was non-nuclear. In response to the fifth part of Senator Chipp's question, I am not sure whether the devices in these tests with conventional explosives were dropped from aircraft or whether they were exploded on the ground, in towers or in other ways or whether, if they were dropped from aircraft, the objective was to test the radioactive fallout in the event of a plane crash. I will check that out. I recall that one of the tests was supposed to simulate whether a nuclear explosion was likely to be triggered if there was a nuclear weapon on an aircraft which had crashed. From the limited investigations I have made of this I understand that a nuclear explosion for that particular type of weapon that was being examined was not likely to take place.

Senator Chipp asked whether the Government has received advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs to the effect that under no circumstances are the British to be offended and a couple of related questions. I do not know whether Foreign Affairs has given such advice. I have not received such advice from Foreign Affairs, and as far as I know nobody else in the Government has. I will have that checked out.

Independently of what the opinion of the Department of Foreign Affairs might be -I think I mentioned this last week-there is a very good reason to show some respect for what the British regard as being confidential information, if only for the reason that it is believed that information relevant to personnel who were on site at the time of the test is still held by the British. Amongst other things, this is information which ultimately could be valuable to the Australian Government in determining its attitude to common law actions initiated for compensation. It seems to be beyond dispute that if the Australian Government showed no respect whatsoever for information derived from United Kingdom sources , which information that Government believes should be kept confidential, we would have no chance of obtaining additional information from the United Kingdom Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That happened on Australian soil.

—I know it happened on Australian soil. However, again to be fair to the British, the Australian Government invited, one might even say begged, the British to come here to do the tests. Senator Chipp probably was not suggesting this, but I think it is unfair to blame the British for everything that happened there. I suggest that the Australian Government of the day was equally culpable. We are dealing with the 1980s and not the 1950s now. For the reason that I have explained, even if for no other reason, I believe there is some very considerable obligation on the Australian Government to be sensitive to the wishes of the British Government. Having said that, I want to commend the British Government and particularly the British High Commission in Canberra for the speed with which they responded to the request, issued as late as last Thursday afternoon, for British approval to release the full contents of the Pearce report. Within 16 hours we had a positive response to this request, and consequently the report was tabled on Friday. There is no intention by this Government to engage in a cover-up nor, I believe, in spite of some of the beat- ups that have appeared in the Press from time to time, including a number of newspapers in the last week, is there any evidence whatsoever that the Australian Government is interested in engaging in a cover-up.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION: DISCRIMINATION IN AUSTRALIAN UNIVERSITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to the statement from the Human Rights Commission referring to discrimination in Australian universities? Can the Minister comment on the claim that our universities 'far from being the leaders in good practice as one might expect, are in fact laggards'? Would the Minister agree that recent challenges to our universities with reference to racial discrimination, while very important, mask the continuing discrimination in regard to opportunities for women in higher academic posts in our universities? What steps has the Government taken to date to deal specifically with discrimination, especially against women in our universities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to note that increasingly attention is being paid to discrimination that exists in our universities. It has been my view, and it is one which I have stated in several public forums, that universities of all places ought to be able to adopt non-discriminatory practices. One does expect a level of enlightenment and commitment to rational policies within our universities that one might not expect to achieve quite so readily is some other areas. However, the facts documenting discrimination against women in particular -but I think other forms of discrimination have existed from time to time-reveal a different picture. A number of statements recently have drawn attention to the very unbalanced pattern of employment within universities. By now it is probably quite well known, in this chamber at least, that only 2 per cent of professors are women. That pattern of imbalance persists through all levels of employment within universities. There can be no claim that this represents the capacities of women because women have had access to universities in this country for about a century and, where they have had equal opportunity have consistently performed at outstanding levels. There might be some social explanations to do with child- rearing and so forth that would explain a lower percentage of woman professors than men, but certainly there is no proper or rational explanation for the fact that only 2 per cent of our professors are women.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been pleased to note that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee in a recent statement acknowledged this imbalance and expressed, in very general terms I might say, an intention to take some steps to rectify it. Similarly, the Human Rights Commission has drawn attention to it. I believe that we can look forward now to some changes. A series of changes will come about as a result of universities, along with all other areas of Commonwealth employment and higher education institutions, being covered by the Government's Sex Discrimination Act . That will mean that, in their hiring practices, their promotion practices and so on, universities will not be able to use irrelevant criteria in making decisions and they will not be able to use such irrelevant criteria as sex, material status or possible capacity to bear children. So we will see some improvements and some changes as a result of that.

I think we will see more basic and widespread changes as a result of universities adopting equal employment opportunity plans. That will come about as a result of the Government's affirmative action policies. Because we are now awaiting the imminent announcement by the Prime Minister of the Government's intentions with regard to affirmative action I will not go into detail at this stage. I think the kinds of discrimination that have occurred in the past are now recognised by all parties, which is the first step, and that there will be an active and constructive approach to removing these discriminations and an active partnership between the Government, the Vice-Chancellors, the staff associations and the students themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer the Attorney to the answer he gave Senator Durack on 30 March, when he said he would consider making public, as an exposure draft, the proposed legislation for a national Bill of Rights. Despite the Government's obvious desire to keep this and other contentious issues off the political agenda until the premature early election, has the Attorney yet decided whether he will let the Australian people see, before the election, what the Government has in mind for them?

—The honourable senator will just have to curb his racing hormones. No decision has been made in this respect. The Government is not in a position to make any announcement as to the content of this Bill.

—Can the Minister for Resources and Energy advise the Senate whether the Government is satisfied that, in view of various statements from the Opposition, there are good prospects for the development and implementation of a bipartisan resources rent tax policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I and the Government had hoped that we might be able to secure at least a wide degree of bipartisan support for a resources rent tax and the taxation of the mining or resources industry in general. I still have some hopes that we might be able to achieve some bipartisan policy, but I am afraid that a truly bipartisan policy no longer appears to be possible. Indeed, one could go beyond that and say that, on the evidence that is available on the public record , there is no indication that the Liberal Party of Australia has a unilateral policy on resource taxation, let alone the Government and the Liberal Party having a bipartisan policy. The Liberal Party seems to have a great deal of difficulty in deciding just what its policy is on this question, let alone what its judgment vis-a-vis the Government policy is. At the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Conference in Hobart on 10 April, Senator Chaney said:

ANSWER.PARA: If after the consultative process the Government in fact put in new tax measures--
the tax measures he was referring to were the ones which were ultimately announced a week or so later-
which have the support of the industry, I would not automatically say that these policies should be changed just because there has been a change of government.
But the next day, at the National Press Club in Canberra, Mr Peacock was asked this question by a Business Review Weekly journalist:

Could you explain please your intentions with regard to the taxation of new oil . Firstly, would you repeal the proposed levy which the Labor Party is going to impose on the Fortescue oil field in Bass Strait? And secondly would you also repeal the proposed resources rent taxation which the Labor Party intends to impose on Greenfields?

Mr Peacock's reply, which was very short, was: 'Yes, Yes'. Mr Peacock said that both of those measures would be repealed by a Liberal government or a coalition government, notwithstanding the fact that only the day before Senator Chaney had said that such measures would not necessarily be repealed. So the Liberal Party cannot make up its own mind what its policy is on this question. Even if the Liberal Party could make up its own mind, whether the Liberal Party in coalition with the National Party would be allowed to implement that policy would still remain a matter for wide-eyed conjecture. Indeed, experience of coalition governments, particularly during the Fraser period, suggested that the Liberal Party was not allowed to implement any of its policies unless it had approval from the National Party to do so.

So we have two levels of confusion here: Confusion within the Liberal Party and doubt as to whether Liberal Party policy, if it had one, would be able to be implemented by a coalition government. But unfortunately in neither case does it seem likely that the sort of wide area, at least of bipartisan support, exists for the very sensible policies the Government has introduced. Nevertheless, I retain some hope that the more responsible and more rational people in the Liberal Party will come to recognise that the policies the Government has announced are sound and ought to be continued even under a future government and that the more courageous people in the Liberal Party, in their next term of office if they have one, will have the courage to do what they did not do last time; that is, stand up to the National Party and implement Liberal Party policy instead of National Party policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Government continues to remind the electorate of its determination to fight tax avoidance. But now that it is armed with anti- avoidance Part IVA instituted by former Treasurer John Howard, could the Minister advise the Senate how many cases are before the courts where the Commissioner of Taxation has applied Part IVA? Further, how many cases does the Commissioner have in the pipeline awaiting a hearing, using this anti-avoidance provision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson has asked: How many cases pursuant to Part IVA are either before the courts or are in the pipeline before the Commissioner of Taxation? I think that was the substance of his question. The short answer is: I do not know how many there are. I will endeavour to obtain that information. However, if one shared the views and stated beliefs of the former Government on this question there should not be any such cases. As I recall Mr Howard's statement at the time he was saying: 'Once Part IVA has been passed there will be no more tax avoidance or evasion of that type'. If Mr Howard's judgment was correct, there should be no such cases nor should there be any possibility of such cases being brought. The Government, though, of course, does not have explicit powers of direction over the Commissioner on matters such as this.

ANSWER.PARA: The Labor Party's view, when in opposition, and it remains its view in Government, is that the most effective way-indeed one could say the only failsafe way-of dealing with blatant tax avoiders and tax evaders is the credible threat of retrospective legislation so that tax avoiders and evaders know that even if they can fool the Commissioner for a while, even if they manage to get a favourable judgment from an eccentric, or worse, High Court of Australia, providing a government of the day has the determination to do so they will still ultimately have to pay their tax obligations. Therefore, there is no point in devising or implementing artificial, contrived tax evasion or avoidance schemes. Unfortunately, there is no such credible threat because people such as Senator Watson insist on voting against legislation that would make such a threat and such a policy credible. Therefore, hope lingers on in the breasts of potential or actual tax evaders and avoiders that they will be allowed to get away with their anti-social activities in the future as they have, to a substantial degree, in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of the recent decision by Ciba-Geigy Australia Ltd to close down its pharmaceutical manufacturing plant at Smithfield in Sydney by 1 October 1984 at a loss of some 80 jobs? One of the reasons listed by Ciba-Geigy for that decision was its concern over the Government's generic policy. Is there any basis in its claim that the extremely low selling prices for its products under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the second stage of the Government's generic policy were major factors in the decision to close down its Smithfield manufacturing operations? Does the Government know of any other companies in the pharmaceutical industry which are facing similar difficulties? Will the Government negotiate with Ciba-Geigy to ensure that no hardship is caused either to those people who reply on the drugs formerly produced by the company or to the retrenched employees of the company?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Ciba-Geigy intends to close its Smithfield operation. I think the job loss involved is about 80. Ciba-Geigy's close-down is part of a reconstruction of its pharmaceutical manufacturing operations in this country and, one could say, part of a general restructuring of pharmaceutical operations by such companies in this country. This is not surprising in view of the fact that most informed people in the area, including I hope Senator Townley , would accept the fact that there was a considerable over-expansion in this area in the 1960s and 1970s.
—Do you mean that manufacturing has over expanded in this country?

—Yes. Senator Baume does not accept that that is so. The pharmaceutical industry does. I assume that Senator Baume is arguing that we should maintain an artificially high price for the pharmaceuticals we are purchasing through the national pharmaceutical system in order to maintain companies like Ciba-Geigy at the scale at which they are operating.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the problems which, interestingly enough, arose on a well-known television program last night has been the operations of companies such as the Ciba-Geigy and Roche companies throughout the world which have indulged in transfer pricing and artificial pricing arrangements in countries such as Australia. They maintain their operations in countries at this level at the expense of patients and governments. Ciba-Geigy, if I remember rightly, had problems in this country with the price of hydralazine-I may be incorrect in naming that substance-and other drugs. It claimed that the prices offered in this country were too low whereas, in fact, it was selling them at much lower prices in other countries. The pricing of pharmaceuticals in this country is the result of negotiations between the companies and the Government. This Government has, and I believe the previous government had, no intention of being ripped off by large multinational companies indulging in transfer pricing of this type to the detriment of the patients and the government.

I believe that Ciba-Geigy's close-down is part of a general restructuring of that company. There is no evidence I believe-I will seek further information from the Minister for Health-that any patient in this country will suffer from the lack of drugs produced at the Smithfield operation. All I can say is that Ciba-Geigy's operations in this country have been under a process of reconstruction for some time. I will certainly seek information from both the Minister for Health and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations as to the likelihood of the people who have lost their jobs in this area receiving similar work in the industry in Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

Can the Minister confirm reports that the Australian Conservation Foundation, through Dr Mosley, has complained to the Minister for Science and Technology that a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation representative supported a resolution at the Australian Timber Industry Stabilisation Conference criticising the Australian Conservation Foundation's forestry policy as being in conflict with the national conservation strategy for Australia, in direct opposition to sound forestry practice, and posing a real threat to the future of Australia's forests, forest industries and the community? Does the Minister share Dr Mosley's description of this person-an employee of CSIRO-as a government officer? Does the Minister agree that it would be entirely inappropriate for the Government to direct CSIRO to dissociate itself publicly from the officer, in line with Dr Mosley's complaint? Does the Minister believe that a CSIRO expert has not only a right but also a duty to contribute to public debate on environmental issues, and at least as much right to do so as officers of the Australian Conservation Foundation which is also a substantially publicly funded organisation? —I have no knowledge of the detailed matters covered in Senator Martin's question, so I will refer the matter to the Minister for Science and Technology and get a detailed reply.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As a Cabinet Minister, the Minister would have a view on the Government's policy in relation to CSIRO, and the last part of my question was: Does the Government believe that CSIRO is independent of political direction?

But as I have no information about the particular matter which has led to some sort of charge about the Government undermining or eroding CSIRO's information, I think the best course of action is that which I have offered to undertake; that is, to refer the matter to the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recently published report of a survey of New South Wales school children's drug taking habits? Does the Minister agree that there is cause for alarm in the drug usage indicated by the report? What action is contemplated to co-operate with the States in taking steps to overcome this problem, particularly in the area of the sniffing of solvents and aerosols by teenagers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read in a newspaper over the weekend about the survey conducted in New South Wales by, I think, the Education Department, which indicated that there was a further increase in the use and abuse of drugs, illicit and otherwise, by school children, particularly in that State. In particular, I remember that mention was made of the relatively high percentage of students who had indulged in the very dangerous practice of sniffing solvents and various aerosol products. I know honourable senators are aware of the very real problems in the Aboriginal community of people sniffing petroleum products.

ANSWER.PARA: It is always disappointing when, given that there has been so much publicity in recent years about the use and abuse of drugs, this sort of survey indicates a problem is continuing to be present and is, in fact, getting worse. It is indicative, I believe, of a social problem which faces not only Australia but the whole world. Certainly this Government will co-operate with the Government of New South Wales or any of the State governments in trying to introduce an effective and efficient drug education program in an effort to cut down the amount of abuse of this type. A second approach would be to introduce safer products on the market to avoid exposure of young people to these substances and their abuse of these substances. I note that in Ireland recently a solvent for inclusion in glues was developed which is not volatile, as are the solvents that are used now. It will certainly be of assistance in this area. The basic problem is why young people-indeed, people of all ages-abuse drugs in this way. I will refer to the Minister for Health-

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you support the setting up of a select committee?

—I was not aware that Senator Kilgariff wanted a select committee . But certainly, the problem the honourable senator has raised in this place in the past, that is, of petrol sniffing amongst Aborigines, is very serious. I will certainly convey to the Minister for Health Senator Robertson's concern in this area and find out what correspondence he has had, with the New South Wales Government in particular, in regard to this issue. Certainly, I accept the fact, as I did many years ago when I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare looking into this matter, that we need a more effective Commonwealth-State Government program to attack this very serious problem.

—Has the Minister for Resources and Energy received the interdepartmental committee report on the trade implications of any decision to cancel the shipment of yellowcake due to be made to France in October? Is it true that the report recommends against any such action on the basis that it would have serious repercussions for Australia's trade with members of the European Economic Community? Will the Government's decision on the shipment be made before or after the Australian Labor Party National Conference in July?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney referred in his question to an interdepartmental committee report. As I recall it, there was an interdepartmental committee report on the question of uranium exports which was received around six months ago, although the honourable senator should not take that as a precise date. Again, as I recall it, that report was not confined to the question of the effects of terminating supplies to France-of placing a continuing embargo on the supplies to France while it continues to test atomic weapons. No interdepartmental committee report on France has been received since. However, I have received an opinion from the Department of Resources and Energy. Two other departments, I think, are also putting in an opinion-or may have already put one in-to the Department of Resources and Energy, or their own Ministers may have done so. I am not sure which is the case.
—Trade and Foreign Affairs?

—Yes. I will not give an undertaking on whether the contents of those departmental reports will be released or whether the contents of them will be discussed in the Senate because, although I will consider this again, I think they probably ought to be regarded as internal government working policy documents.
