TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and, in particular, for the fairly definite statement he made at the end of it. I also ask him: Will he confirm that position with the Minister for Trade? Will he mind confirming whether that view is also the view of the Minister for Trade whom he represents in this place?

—I am the Acting Minister for Trade today; so I suppose I can confirm that view here and now. Since I do not expect to have that exalted position for very much longer, when Mr Lionel Bowen returns I will seek his views on the matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. What is the current situation regarding the Tasmanian Government's offer of $3m to upgrade Hobart Airport? Has it been decided what the money will be spent on? Has any comparison been made between the benefits of spending the money at Hobart or spending it at Launceston?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate indicated that he wanted to ask a question about the allocation of funds in respect of aviation matters in Tasmania. I sought a response from the Minister for Aviation, whom I represent in this place. Mr Beazley has provided me with the following information. In commenting upon the Commonwealth's Gordon below Franklin offset package, Mr Gray advised that he intended to spend $3m of State funds on the upgrading of Hobart Airport. Discussions between the Commonwealth and State officials have identified the alternatives as either the lengthening of the runway from 1,980 metres to 2,480 metres, or extending the terminal to provide for two-way B767 loading and carpark improvements. This proposed expenditure by Mr Gray is in addition to $3m provided by the Commonwealth for the upgrading of Hobart Airport as part of the Gordon below Franklin offset package. The Commonwealth funds will cover pavement works consisting of runway turning nodes, taxiway fillets and apron extensions, costing $2.4m; and technical capital works consisting of provision of taxiing lights, apron floodlighting and distance measuring equipment costing $0.2m, which will leave $0.4m for other works. This could be used to enlarge the terminal building to cater for two-way flow of B727 loads.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to interest from the Launceston community, Mr Beazley advises that he has had the potential for upgrading of that airport investigated and that it is indicated that the upgrading of Launceston to international standards would cost between $40m and $55m, and that that is currently out of the question. However, as some interest has been expressed in flying wide-bodied aircraft into Launceston, which has advantages as a point of entry for domestic tourists, he indicates that for about $3m, say, a turning node at the end of the runway, an apron at one end of the terminal and a short taxiway connecting the apron to the runway could be provided. These improvements would enable the domestic airlines to fly B767s or Airbuses to Launceston if they believed that the market justified the expansion in capacity. So it appears that the Premier has decided that further upgrading of Hobart has top priority and the final decision, as the Federal Government accepts, is his. Whatever the Premier decides, the Department of Aviation and the Government will continue to give every assistance in the administration of that expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Education. Is the Minister aware that a very sizable and increasing number of Australian parents from all socio-economic backgrounds are sending their children to private schools because they see that they get a better education from private as opposed to government schools? Will the Minister, therefore, cease the Labor campaign against private schools and tackle the heart of the problem, which is the teachers' union and its members in government schools, who are more interested in teaching radical and rabid political theories, thereby enhancing their chances as candidates, as Labor Party representatives, than teaching legitimate academic subjects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that I have to take that question seriously and try to give some sort of answer to it, even though it was obviously a dreadful bit of anti-teacher rhetoric. Senator MacGibbon's questions touched on a couple of issues of general interest, so I shall make a couple of comments. The facts about the movement in some States at some times of some children from the government school system to the non-government school system have been thoroughly documented by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. I refer Senator MacGibbon to its most recent report, which sets out those figures in some detail . From that he will see that although overall there has been a statistical shift , in some cases it has been a shift in the other direction. Quite clearly when parents have the opportunity to make these sorts of choices, that opportunity is presented through government funding of many different kinds of schools throughout Australia. Some parents are also in the financial circumstances to make those sorts of choices, and they make them. That is the situation which our Government recognises and indeed assists in many ways. I certainly do not think one can infer from the fact that parents make different kinds of choices that the kinds of outrageous claims that Senator MacGibbon made about teachers are to be in any way taken seriously.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator MacGibbon also referred gratuitously and grossly incorrectly to the Labor Government's campaign against private schools. I simply point out to Senator MacGibbon again that in our first Budget, our 1984 Budget, the Hawke Labor Government spent more money on non-government schools than has ever been spent by any previous government in this country and, in doing so, gave real increases to the vast majority of non-government schools. In excess of 90 per cent of non-government schools got more funding under the Hawke Labor Government 's first Budget than under the previous Government's Budgets or under the previous Government's formula for assisting schools. The change that we made with respect to our support for the non-government sector was to redirect assistance to those schools most in need, and that strategy by and large has been endorsed throughout the non-government schools sector.

Finally, I must comment on the gratuitous and insulting remarks that Senate MacGibbon made about teachers. It has been my experience, having now spent 12 months visiting schools of all kinds in all parts of Australia, that the various teaching services which Australian children have to serve them are made up of highly qualified and committed people. As in any profession, there are some people whose capacities are greater than others and there are some people whose commitment is greater than others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to mention politicans.
—It is true, as the Attorney-General remarks by way of interjection , that this is true even of politicians.
—And dentists.

—And dentists. Some work harder than others; some have more ability than others; and some have more commitment than others. But by and large, I would say that Australian school children, be they in government systems in our six States and two Territories or in the variety of non-government schools which our Government funds and will continue to fund, are well served by their teachers.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is the Minister disputing the fact that an increasing number of students are going to private schools as opposed to public schools?

—The supplementary question certainly has to be answered with the word no. There are not more children going to private schools than to public schools. On a national average about 75 per cent of children are in government schools and about 25 per cent are in non-government schools. That varies from State to State. In Tasmania, for example, only 15 per cent of children are in non-government schools. If we look at national statistics we will see that in the last few years, since the inception of the very free way of funding the development of new places in non-government schools, there has been a percentage increase nationally, but not in every State or at every level of schooling, towards private schooling. That, I might say, is counter to the direction in the late 1960s and early 1970s when the trend was the other way. Obviously there are changes in social attitudes. There are slight movements. But by and large three- quarters of our children are in government schools and a quarter are in the vast variety of non-government schools. I expect that situation will continue more or less as the average with which our Government has to cope and for which we will develop policies which are both equitable to both sectors and rational in the economic use of the resources that the taxpayer provides.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Bearing in mind the close interest expressed in the issue by several honourable senators, can the Attorney-General advise whether there has been any development over the past month in the consideration by the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Temby , of the prosecution of Foreign Affairs officer Don Witheford which, as far back as 16 March, was criticised by the Acting Chief Magistrate as being conceived in prejudice and born in bias on the part of some Foreign Affairs officers?

—I have no further information to give the Senate as to the progress the Director of Public Prosecutions may be making in his consideration of the question of appeal from Mr Dobson's decisions and also whether the remaining two charges should proceed. It is some time since I had my last brief on this matter though and I will inform Senator Primmer as soon as I can what the outcome is. However, in the meantime I remind him and the Senate that Mr Witheford continues to be suspended from duty on full pay.

—I refer to the Government's proposed changes to the Trade Practices Act which were the subject of election undertakings, a Green Paper and exposure draft legislation. Such changes would be very valuable. It is a pity the Government is not proceeding in the same way in relation to a Bill of Rights . I refer in particular to the Government's proposal to repeal sections 45D and 45E, which provide for outlawing secondary boycotts. I ask the Attorney: Is it the Government's intention to proceed immediately or in the near future with the abolition of section 45D and 45E, certainly before the premature early election it is planning, or will this promise join other contentious issues on the back burner?

—The timetable governing the Government's introduction of the legislation specifically to repeal sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, to which we are committed, will be governed by our consideration of the responses to the Green Paper, and in particular the discussion paper, as to the relationship between trade practices law and the trade unions so far as it affects the question of alternative means of dispute resolution in this area. As the Government has clearly and quite explicitly acknowledged in that discussion paper, it is accepted that there is a need, whether through the conciliation and arbitration machinery or otherwise, to have some effective method for resolving the problems that have arisen and will continue to arise in this area. It is certainly not the Government's intention to leave the field completely open in this respect. But as I say, the timetable will be governed by the responses when they are received. The responses were due this week. A number of business and other organisations have requested extensions of time within which to lodge responses to the Green Paper. I am not able to give any firmer indication than that as to the timetable.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Government's legislative response to implementing its policy in relation to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act be according to the same timetable as that for its response to its proposals for the whole of the legislation?
—I have nothing further to add to the answer I just gave to the question, Mr President. It is not possible at this stage to be precise as to what that timetable will be.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware that the previous Liberal-National Party Government ceased to provide public toilet facilities at Australia House in London and, more importantly, ceased the publication of a regular news bulletin which was a valuable resource both for Australian travellers and overseas business people? Does the Government intend to restore these services and, if so, when?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov gave some advance notice of her concern about the situation in respect of public conveniences at Australia House. As a result I am able to say that I am well briefed on the matter by the Department of Foreign Affairs. Extraordinarily and perhaps appropriately enough, that brief comes to me in the form of a cablegram classified restricted. I am able to advise the honourable senator that the toilet facilities previously available to the public were located in the lower basement of Australia House but that following the introduction of revised security arrangements in Australia House in October 1975 they were no longer accessible from the ground floor public areas. In August 1982, when the Migration Branch moved from Canberra House to Australia House, new toilet facilities were installed in a self-contained upper basement area for use by the public attending migration interviews. For reasons of security other members of the public must be escorted--

—Mr President, I rise to a point of order. Several Opposition senators are seeking the call for a question. I suggest that the Minister incorporate his answer in Hansard. We might then be able to get on with the business of the place.
—There is no point of order.

—I was in the course of telling the Senate that for reasons of security other members of the public must be escorted to and from the toilet facilities in the lower basement. I cannot forbear but to seek leave to incorporate the rest of this answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —More generally, however, they are directed to public toilets about 100 yards from the front of Australia House and at the rear of St Clement Danes Church. There are architectural as well as functional reasons--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. First of all I make it clear that it was not the Opposition which denied leave for the incorporation of the rest of the answer. The fact of the matter is that Ministers can treat Question Time with contempt in a number of ways. Giving long answers is the usual way. Mr President, I suggest to you that there are honourable senators on this side who wish to ask questions and that they should be given the opportunity. The Minister should be sat down.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Attorney-General sought leave to have the rest of the answer incorporated and leave was not given. I ask the Attorney-General to conclude the answer.

—Mr President, I will endeavour to compose myself. There are architectural as well as functional reasons which preclude the installation of toilets in the ground floor public areas of Australia House. Restoration of access to such facilities elsewhere in the building has security implications necessitating the use of escorts, which has undesirable practical and social consequences.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the latter part of the question, which deals with bulletins and which, as Senator Zakharov says, is perhaps a matter of rather greater substance, until early 1981 an edited version of the Radio Australia news transcription was given wide circulation. The Australian Information Service's cabled summary of extracts from the Australian daily Press then became the basis of a daily news sheet entitled Australia News. It is circulated by mail to the United Kingdom Press and a selected list of Australians resident in Britain. Copies are also available at Australia House. Postage costs were the reason for restricting the mailing list. There do not appear to be any plans afoot to repair the depredations of the former Government in respect of these matters of the location of toilets and information newsletters, but the situation clearly will be kept under review as a result of the interest shown in the matter by Senator Zakharov and other honourable senators.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. My question concerns the British nuclear tests at Maralinga and elsewhere. I ask: Was there in existence throughout the Maralinga, Emu and Monte Bello testings an Australian committee known as the Atomic Weapons Testing Advisory Committee or a similar name? Secondly, did the Committee include expert scientists and senior public servants? Thirdly, did the Committee have continuous liaison with the British personnel managing the tests and did the Committee advise the Australian Government of the day of the safety, timing, weather and other factors? Fourthly, are the relevant documents of the Committee and of other sources available in the Australian Archives? Fifthly, are some of the Committee members still alive? Finally, over the years and in the face of a number of allegations of carelessness or injury in the tests, has any evidence of such carelessness or injury emerged from the approaches by the governments of the day to the existing sources, both human and record?

—I believe there was a Committee with the same or similar name to that which Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned. Whether it was in existence throughout the entire period of atomic testing, I do not know. I will have that checked out. Likewise I will have it checked out whether the Committee reported regularly to governments and did the sorts of things contained in the question. I had decided before Senator Sir John Carrick asked his question, having been prompted by reports which have appeared in the last few weeks concerning readings of radioactive fallout, to collect information on the readings. It is worth making a distinction, I think, between radioactive fallout and total radiation. Reports, even if correct-I think some of them have been correct-that there was a hundred-fold increase in radioactive fallout at a particular site following a test, as is reported in today's Age, do not mean that there was a hundred-fold increase in total radioactivity because the fallout increased from a negligible figure to something which was 100 times a negligible figure and the background radioactivity was very much greater than the increased fallout level, let alone the pre-existing fallout level. I think that ought to be seen in perspective. I have decided to collect, if it can be done, all the readings of radioactive fallout which were taken in Australia during that period. As to whether there is any evidence of carelessness, I think one could say, with the wisdom of hindsight, that it was pretty careless and irresponsible to conduct the program at all. But the perceptions of the 1950s were different from the perceptions of the 1980s. I am aware of a couple of other specific happenings that I think could be regarded as careless, but an opinion on whether or not they are careless is rather subjective.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In making his inquiries, will the Minister contact those members of the Committee who are still alive? Will he seek from them and from the Australian Archives the more broad answers to the questions that have been raised in recent days?
—Yes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 May Senator Primmer asked me a series of questions about the Witheford case. He asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that a private Sydney barrister by the name of Hastings has been retained for the past several months at a cost of tens of thousands of dollars to assist Foreign Affairs officers working on Mr Witheford's prosecution? Is that barrister still working out of the Department of Foreign Affairs? If so, will the Attorney provide full details of Mr Hasting's hiring, including the costs involved and the level of security clearance--

I am able to advise him, on behalf of both myself and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, as follows: The question is in three parts. As to the first and second parts, the answer is no. In the circumstances, the third part of the question does not arise. I would add for the record, however, that Mr Hastings was briefed through the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in the matter of the proceedings against Mr Witheford at a daily rate of $500 plus a loading of $250 for any day on which he was required to travel to Canberra and of $150 a day for any day on which he remained in Canberra. His account in an amount of $3,590 has been received. That amount covers all work done other than two short advices which might have involved a further half day's work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also on 3 May, Senator Scott asked a question about the school cadet corps. I seek leave to incorporate an answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer reads as follows-

On 1 March, 1984 the Minister for Defence announced that the Australian Army Cadet Corps was being restructured after full consideration of a large number of submissions from schools. The new scheme will begin operating from 1 July 1984.

The scheme will be based on regional units, open to the community. This will ensure that they are open to all eligible young people. Units will be centred on Army Reserve depots rather than at schools.
Those units already operating on a community-based system with full Army support will continue to receive that support.
A number of economically disadvantaged schools will also continue to receive full Army support for their cadet units. These units are expected to be opened to the community in due course.

All other schools wishing to retain affiliation with the Australian Army Cadet Corps will receive only limited support from the Army. Limited support will include the training but not payment of officers of cadets. Uniforms and equipment will be provided, but the schools will have to pay for them.

While the Government accepts that the cadet corps, like the Boy Scouts and similar organizations, have social value, they have little or no military value and expenditure from the defence vote must be directed towards priorities for defence preparedness. Otherwise the taxpayer will not receive the maximum for each defence dollar. The cost of the present scheme in 1983-84 is $11m.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on 29 March you asked me a question about the Queen's capacity when she made a speech in Jordan. Again, I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer reads as follows-
The Queen is Head of State of 17 Commonwealth countries including the United Kingdom and Australia.
When the Queen visits one of these countries she does so as Head of State of the country concerned.

I take the honourable senator's question to be directed at visits by the Queen to countries outside the Commonwealth. The position is governed largely by practice and convention and depends upon the basis on which the invitation to visit a particular country is made and accepted. In most cases the Queen will have been invited to visit the country concerned in her capacity as Head of State of the United Kingdom. The visit will therefore be undertaken in that capacity and she will speak in that capacity, acting on the advice of the United Kingdom Government. This would be understood and appreciated by the host Government.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Messner proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The destruction of security in retirement for Australians by the Hawke Labor Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: 3.14)-The matter of public importance before the Senate is:

SPEECH.PARA: The destruction of security in retirement for Australians by the Hawke Labor Government.

I believe this is a matter of the highest level of concern in Australia today. Perhaps this matter of public importance could not have been brought on at a better time with the return of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) fresh from his recent trip overseas where, no doubt, he has found new ideas with which to assail the pensioners of Australia. Of course, he will have the immediate opportunity of setting people's minds at rest with his new intentions and, therefore, will be able to take them into his fullest confidence. We hope that he will be able to engender that confidence in people in those circumstances. His absence has brought joy to some of these people already.

The Hawke Labor Government has brought great confusion to the aging in our community and has created a political divide where there existed broad bipartisan understanding in the past. Its actions, which I would like to deal with a little later in detail, have destroyed the system and the confidence which Australians have shown in it for many years and have undermined the future ability of governments to provide for the aging. Far from ensuring security in old age, the Hawke Labor Government is creating an ever-widening pool of Australians who are now worried, concerned and, in many cases terrified, at the proposals which Mr Hawke and Senator Grimes have in store for them as they approach old age. Without doubt the twin policy lines of encouragement to provide for oneself through tax incentives and the underpinning of that system with a government pension have served Australia well in the past. Some commentators would have us believe that this system is inequitable, inadequate and unable to distribute assistance to the most needy.

I shall now seek to demonstrate that this is not true and that such a dual system, which encourages thrift and independence, is vastly superior in all respects from one which seeks to make Australians totally dependent on government handouts. This Government has brought about three major changes in the area of retirement income policy: Firstly, the reintroduction of both an income test and an assets test for the over 70-year-olds; secondly, the announcement and the bringing forward of legislation on an assets test for all pensioners; and thirdly, although we have not seen any legislation yet, nearly 12 months on from the date when the first announcement was made, there is to be taxation on lump sum superannuation payments.

In respect of the over 70-year-olds, an income test has been imposed since 1 November last year. As a consequence of that policy 55,000 people have had their pensions stopped. So 55,000 people are worse off under the Hawke Labor Government. The introduction of the assets test, announced in the August Budget, has brought confusion right from its very start. The Minister for Social Security and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) embarked upon an alleged consultative program whereby they met with all those groups and organisations that were supposed to be involved. This left very little time for those groups to grasp the concept and make any thoughtful comments on it.

In its original form the assets test included many anomalies which we do not need to reiterate. Suffice it to say that it obviously favoured the wealthier people in the community, while it tended to penalise those of modest means who, through thrift, had saved during their working lives. Legislation for this assets test was not sighted until December 1983. Initially the Government sought to drive it through Parliament as fast as it could. The action of the Opposition , in conjunction with the Australian Democrats, brought about a delay in that legislation, at least until February. However, a conference was held in February , sponsored by the Australian Council of Social Services, which represented many organisations right across the country. This conference lambasted the assets test proposal and noted in its report:

The strong sentiment, virtually unanimous among pensioner groups, was that the Government might better institute a review of the income security system in conjunction with its review of the taxation system. That path of change should yield fewer anomalies than the one chosen.

Mr Deputy President, this statement endorses the Opposition's position on this matter right from day one. In fact, as you would know, in September 1983 the Opposition sought, and successfully had carried, a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare on the question of retirement income generally. As a consequence of these matters and growing public criticism of the assets test, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced in February, without consulting the Minister, Senator Grimes, that Cabinet would review the decision. In announcing Cabinet's review of the assets test policy the Prime Minister again endorsed the Opposition's attitude by stating:
It has become clear that there is continuing and justifiable concern about whether the Government has yet found the best way to implement legislation on an assets test in a fair and equitable way.

If ever there was masterpiece of understatement it was that statement. Cabinet has established an independent panel to review the assets test. This panel, we believe, is due to announce its decision by 30 June. As a consequence of this Government's mishandling of the whole assets test an estimated $11m was spent by the Department of Social Security alonw in anticipation of the program. More than 1,500 employees were put on in anticipation of the test.

Let us leave aside that disaster and turn to another-the changes to lump sum superannuations. I remind the Senate that it is now almost 12 months since the Government announced that it was about to introduce taxation on lump sum superanuation payments. After all that time we have still seen no legislation. We do not know whether the Government has determined its final attitude in that respect and in what way it will impact on peoples' lives. In fact, people are forced to go on making decisions in the light of this most unreasonable situation which any person would abhor. The original proposals in July, which have been changed from the May proposals, were to make tax payable at 30 per cent on all lump sums. Other changes have been made in respect of Defence Force personnel and the amounts they will receive. I make the point that the tax is purely confiscatory and has behind it only an ideological bent which has been so badly thought out. I will demonstrate that more clearly in a moment.

The Australian Labor Party is opposed to lump sum payments because they make people independent from government and such an outcome is incompatible with its policy objectives of making people dependent on government. Labor's rhetoric in all these changes has been that it wishes to assist those in greatest need. But the present system already does that and that has been admitted by Senator Grimes in his own publications-I refer to Labor Essays 1983. By seeking to lower people's independence greater demands will be made upon government resources and this can only reduce its capacity to assist those in greatest need.

In justifying the Government's superannuation changes the Government has, on many occasions, referred to $2,500m in so-called taxation expenditures in respect of occupational superannuation. This large amount of money breaks down into two main elements. The first is about $1,500m. Its results from the tax free treatment of employer and employee contributions to superannuation schemes. The second element of about $1,200m comes from the lack of taxation on the earnings of superannuation fund benefits. Is the Government tying to tell us that the first element of $1,500m, if entirely wiped out, would not be exceeded by the effect of increased drawings on the social security system by people who would then become dependent upon government? I think that is the point it is trying to make, that is, that it would be cheaper for the Government to make everybody dependent. Plainly, that is a nonsense and it is at direct variance with the Opposition's policy in this area. We will not support that policy in forthcoming legislation.

The second element of about $1,200m comes from the reduction of revenue resulting from the non-taxation of the incomes of superannuation funds. Of course, this relates to the ability of superannuation funds to provide future benefits in retirement. If that income is severely reduced superannuation funds will be unable to meet their obligations to pay benefits to employees upon their retirement. As a result of that, people will increasingly become reliant and dependent upon the government pension. The point I make is this: It has been stated by actuaries and by people who are expert in the kind of calculations that this entails that if taxation is applied to the income of superannuation funds at or around the level presently applicable in special circumstancs-that is, about 50 per cent-the ability of superannuation funds to provide benefits will be reduced by up to nine-tenths of the final benefit over a period of 40 years. That means the ability of a superannuation fund to meet its obligation to its members will be absolutely destroyed. I believe that that very significantly draws the point that the Government is on the wrong track in its policy of seeking to tax lump sums and also is very much-as it has already acknowledged-on the wrong track in terms of applying an assets test to pensioners.

The Government does not have to rely on me to make that point. I will quote from some evidence given recently to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare by Mr Daryl Dixon, who is the director of the social welfare policy secretariat within the Minister's Department. On page 78 of the transcript of the meeting of that Committee, in reply to one of my questions with regard to economic growth being a major factor in meeting the future costs of welfare, he is reported as having said:
That is why I think that options that attempt to change the relative emphasis on occupational superannuation are doomed to failure.
I repeat, doomed to failure-

I think that if you were to decide that we are not to rely on occupational superannuation you would then have to work out where else that $20 billion of funds with an additional $1.5 billion per year in savings, or whatever it is, would come from. I think that growth is going to be the key to all this.

I do not think any truer words can be spoken about the nature of the problem and the direction of the solution that must be found than what has been said in public evidence by Mr Daryl Dixon, who is well known to many of us as an expert in this area.

Mr Daryl Dixon's remarks are well supported by other commentators in this area. I refer to a table of a survey in the report of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It was included in a recent article on income and housing. The survey shows in its results that the number of people who are dependent upon government cash benefits as their principal source of income decreases with the amount received as lump sum superannuation. The proportion reliant on government cash benefits as their principle source of income declines from 84 per cent of those with lump sums of less than $5,000 to only 28 per cent, 8,600 people, of those with lump sums of over $50,000. TALK.START.PARA: —The outcome of this is clear. The ability of people to remain independent will be seriously imperilled by the actions of this Government. Some of the actions, of course, have been badly thought out and certainly have been badly accepted in the electorate. The strange thing about all of this is that the Government has singled out the aged for attack. It has not had the guts to introduce a capital gains tax or death duties. It has even backed off from the assets test, merely because it felt the heat of voter disapproval. It has failed over 12 months to introduce legislation for the new tax on lump sum superannuation. The conclusion from those duckings and weavings is clear: There is to be an election this year and the Government does not want any issues around which might put it in any kind of bad light. I am amazed that the media has not picked up that point more clealy and said so.

SPEECH.PARA: Naturally enough, the Prime Minister does not want anything to trip him up on his road to his destiny. In particular, he does not want his loyal Corporal Grimes to get in his way, not the least Senator Grimes. The Grimes who introduced the assets test, having promised to increase benefits to pensioners, was the one who was struck down by his own Prime Minister in recent weeks by a blow from the back-not by a Brutus, who at least came from the front to stab his leader, but rather by one from the back. That is obvious and very clear evidence of the lack of stomach on the part of the Prime Minister for the electoral battle. He runs away from issues such as lump sum superannuation and the assets test. Quite frankly, he appears unable to test his arm. Far from being courageous, as he loves to be painted, he is obviously a coward who runs out on each fight at any sign of public disapproval. He obviously has all the principle of a mercenary and in that sense is perhaps better called Mad Mike Hoare.

Worst of all in the way that the Hawke Government, this Prime Minister and this Minister have deceived the Australian public is that they have generated such widespread concern, not just confusion and concern amongst pensioners and their families. Insecurity has been generated amongst all groups-blue collar workers, white collar workers, workers of all collars. The problems that they feel are creeping into the income security system augur disastrous futures for them. They know that this Government cannot be relied upon. It is obviously just waiting to get another election notch under its belt before it lands Australians with a capital gains tax, with an assets test, with more death duties and with more penal legislation, thereby reducing the ability of people to look after themselves. The Government should be warned that the Australian public now knows that. Mr Hawke should beware lest his sleazy ambitions should overtake the trust which was given to him last March.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner referred to the fact that I have been overseas. I admit that that is so. I have just returned and am a bit jetlagged. I tell the Senate, however that Senator Messner has, in fact, been overseas longer than I. He has been to Thredbo for the weekend. We have just heard an extraordinary speech which in the end seemed to reach some sort of strange anatomical level. Senator Messner was talking about people being stabbed from the back and the front, having no stomach, and not being willing to chance their arms. He referred to Brutus and God knows who else in his speech. I suggest that what Senator Messner has demonstrated-whether it is due to jet lag, overseas trips or what-is that any confusion in this area is, in fact, in the minds of Senator Messner and his colleagues and is not in the Government or the electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, Senator Messner made great point of the fact that I had been overeas and said that he hoped I would get up and give some answers to the sorts of problems that he raised. I remind him again that he also has been overseas and was overseas longer than I. He made no reference to his trip because, I dare say , he found that people overseas are also experiencing problems concerning how they should deal with the question of retirement income in their communities. One thing I noticed when I was overseas-I talked to various people at all levels of government and bureaucracy who are dealing with retirement income-was that people view with amazement and wonder the situation which exists in this country whereby we have a superannuation system which provides for tax deductions for superannuation contributions, which provides for tax exemptions for the companies which provide those contributions and which then provides for taxation on only 5 per cent of a lump sum which is paid at the end. They view that with great wonder.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you talk to the people in the United Kingdom?

—Of course I talked to the people in the United Kingdom. Senator Messner knows what the people in the United Kingdom think. I suggest that the problem faced by the people in the United Kingdom is the same as the problem we face. The problem that the conservative Minister in the United Kingdom faces at the moment is a rough equivalent to what Senator Messner and I are talking about ; that is, the very large-sometimes #40,000 or more-severance payments which are made to some people in that country are also, as they are in this country, able to be converted so that they are not considered as income. Those people then receive full pensions, full fringe benefits and the full rate reductions that other people receive in England. My conservative equivalent in England is trying to do something about that. The aim of this Government is not, as Senator Messner suggested, to wipe out occupational superannuation. It is not to wipe out people's capacity to contribute during their working life to their retirement. It is to provide for the existence of superannuation schemes which do what superannuation schemes are supposed to do and which they do in every other country; that is, provide a weekly income on retirement to people.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of the taxation deductions for superannuation payments and the aim of the special treatment, as far as taxation is concerned, of firms which provide occupational superannuation has been and is always stated to be, as Senator Messner will see if he looks at the debates in the past, to encourage people to enter into private superannuation payments so that when they retire they will not be a burden on the age pension system and on the welfare bill in this community. Quite clearly, what has been happening with many of these people, as is well known to Senator Messner and to those involved and those knowledgeable in the area, is that people have been able to take advantage of our system because of lump sum payments and because of the concessional treatment of lump sum payments. They are not only able to receive the full benefits of those superannuation schemes, of those tax deductions and the non-taxation of firms, but are also able then to receive full pensions and full fringe benefits. That is the problem. Senator Messner knows it is the problem. That is what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is all about double dipping?

—It is not all about that. It is about providing a fair and equitable system. Senator Messner knows it. Let us say that we have two people who are neighbours. One is in, say, a Public Service superannuation scheme and receives his or her benefit as weekly payments and therefore loses fringe benefits and part or all of his or her pension. Let us say that next door is a person who has contributed the same amount in superannuation and received the same taxation benefits but who receives a lump sum payment and is able to be taxed on only five per cent of it and then, through some device-those devices have blossomed in this community since the assets test was removed-is able to receive, as well as the benefits of that lump sum payment, the full pension and fringe benefits. There is no way that that system is fair.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two ways out of it. The first is to provide everyone with a full pension and full fringe benefits. The second is to overcome the situation by encouraging superannuation schemes through lump sum taxation or however else to provide weekly superannuation payments. If we go down the first track, which is the inevitable result of the sorts of policies that Senator Messner and the Opposition have talked about and provide everyone with full fringe benefits and full pensions, we can do it in only two ways. The first way is by increasing taxation, because the pensions of today are paid for by the taxpayer of today, and I do not hear anyone from the other side ever advocating that. The second way leads to what inevitably happens in a system such as ours when we try to provide pensions to everyone regardless of need. Those pensions are at inadequate levels, particularly for the low income people who need them most.

I welcome a debate on retirement policy in this country. We should have more such debates. But I do not welcome the sort of debate that we always seem to have on the few occasions when this matter arises. What the present Government decided to do was, first, as has been recommended by many people, including all the national superannuation inquiries, to encourage the development of private superannuation schemes which paid people a weekly income on retirement. One way to do that is to provide for more equitable taxation on lump sums unless people turn those sums into annuitites or other forms of weekly income payments. Another way to do it, as Senator Messner has pointed out, would be to increase the taxation on receipt of those funds. But Senator Messner is opposed to that.

The members of the Opposition are opposed to every suggestion which has been made to make our retirement system fairer. They are opposed to changing the system of taxation on lump sum superannuation. They are opposed to increasing the taxation on the superannuation funds at the point of those funds being paid in. They are opposed to tackling the system in any other way, as I understand it , through, say, capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or any of the methods that are used.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you bringing in a capital gains tax?
—No, I am just saying that the Opposition members are opposed to those sorts of methods, which are used in every country which I suggest that Senator Messner visited.
—He has been proposing such a tax for ages.

—If members of the Opposition, including Senator Walters and Senator Messner, are opposed to all those things, and opposed to the very generous means test which has been introduced on the over-70s pension, which is only an extension of the means test that they introduced-by that stage one is getting to over $1,000m-it is about time that they said what they are in favour of. After all, they have been in government for seven years, and before that they were in government for 23 years. For all that time they administered the pension scheme. For the period of the 23 years before 1976, they administered an assets test. Minister after Minister, including Mr Sinclair and others who are still in this Parliament, administered an assets test. Even Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for a short time administered the assets test. It was administered, and then, suddenly out of the blue, for reasons which have been admitted by Senator Withers, the assets test was removed because of pressure and problems from the Country Party.

SPEECH.PARA: When the assets test was removed, the justification given in this place was that Professor Henderson and the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty had recommended it. But Professor Henderson said that although the removal of the assets test would simplify the application of the means test, it would not be fair and would create all sorts of anomalies unless some method was introduced to stop people abusing that absence of an assets test. He recommended the introduction of a capital gains test at that time. When that assets test was removed, we saw, as I have said, a great blossoming of schemes which were invented by some of the inventive companies in this county to enable people to avoid the income test, to receive the full benefits of their lump sum superannuation payment or whatever assets they had and still to receive full pensions and full fringe benefits, to the detriment of those on low incomes or those with no incomes, who, as a result of that, have seen the real value of their pensions drop from 24.4 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1975, when the previous Liberal Government came to power, to 22.2 per cent later.

The simple fact of the matter is that no conservative or Labor government in this country can perpetuate a system like that. They particularly cannot perpetuate that system, as Mr Daryl Dixon says in the paper he gave to the Committee that Senator Messner was partly instrumental in establishing, if we are to have an aging population as we are going to have in our community as in other Western communities. I do not over-estimate the problems we will face from that aging population in the way some people do. In fact, it will not hit this community as much as it will hit other communities. But it certainly will be a factor, and we cannot persist in providing inadequate pensions and services to those who need them most while those who have the capacity to do so, through our imperfect existing system can get the full benefits of the system when they quite patently do not need them.

It is for that reason that the Government announced that it would introduce an assets test; it was for that reason that the Government wishes to amend the superannuation legislation; and it is for that reason that the Government introduced the income test on the over-70s and an income test which is far more generous than that which is provided for people aged 65 to 69. Senator Messner says that great political difficulties have arisen out of this; people do not like it. Of course, some people in the community do not like it because they are advantaged by the imperfections of the existing system over their brothers and sisters. Of course people do not like it if they can receive the sort of lump sum payments or have the sort of asset levels that Senator Gietzelt pointed out some people have, and yet still get the full benefit of our pensions and our health services, et cetera, without contributing to them. I accept that those who do well out of the existing system will always resist change of that type. Of course the airline pilots, who were working 36 hours a month, and who in some cases received lump payments of $500,000 opposed it to the extent of going on strike. Imagine what would have happened if another group in the community had gone on strike over an issue like that. The howls from Opposition members would have been loud and long.

Of course they oppose it, but still they will not be affected retrospectively. They will still be able to convert either their superannuation entitlements or their lump sums into annuities and not have to put up with that tax. What they will not be able to do is what they should not be able to do-that is, to convert that lump sum into property trusts or whatever and take the full pension and the fringe benefits that go with it. That is what they will not be able to do and that is how the system will become fair. The sort of changes we are continuing to advocate are not the whole answer to the problem.

—You bet you will.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that, quite simply, we need the development of a system which is fair and which does what the existing system is supposed to do, that is, to provide the people of this country with an adequate retirement income by a fair distribution of the funds available to governments in this country to people who have retired so that an unfair burden is not placed on the existing taxpayer and so as not to cause unfair discrimination amongst those relying on the retirement income. What Senator Messner says about the existing dual system, which provides for encouragement by tax incentives and for an underpinning of that by the provision of pensions, quite clearly is not so. The examples given in this place and in the newspapers of this country of people who have taken those generous tax concessions, who have provided themselves with very large capital and asset holdings and who at the same time, on retirement have been able to take advantage of a full pension and full fringe benefits, quite simply cannot continue.

If we have some adequate explanations from the Opposition of how we can overcome the inequities in the existing system and can produce an affordable system which distributes funds on the basis of need to those people who have retired, I will listen to it, but we have not heard that today or in the last 12 months, and I dare say that we will not hear it in the future. At the moment the Opposition is engaging in party political rhetoric in an endeavour to do what Senator Messner accuses the Government of doing, that is, to frighten people to make them resist change for the sake of resisting change. We will not be moved by that sort of rhetoric or political tactic. We will move towards a fair and decent system in this community to provide adequate retirement incomes for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today a matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition which accuses the Hawke Labor Government of destroying security in retirement for Australians. I think it really ought to say that the Hawke Labor Government is making a jolly good attempt to finish the destruction of security in retirement for Australians that started under the previous Government. We have heard a lot today about what does and does not make up security for retirees in this country. What it amounts to is that for most people there are two sorts of security. One, of course, is financial security. For retirees that is the knowledge that, because of their own planning or because of government legislation and provision, they will have enough money to live on or will have enough income from one source or another to get by on for the rest of their lives. The second sort of security that most people of that age group, or indeed of any age group, require is mental and emotional security, that is, the knowledge that they will continue to be able to receive at least enough income to maintain a minimum standard of living, no matter what happens to them and to their assets.

SPEECH.PARA: Thanks to various statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in both May and August last year, there is no question that confusion existed all last year in a significant number of minds in the community. The withdrawal, or alleged withdrawal, of the assets and income test legislation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the National Press Club, which actually turned into putting it on the backburner, did not help those people who were confused, whether or not with any assistance from Opposition senators, about what they could or could not own and what they could or could not do with what they did own if the legislation finally brought before the Parliament was passed and proclaimed. One of the worst aspects of the Govenrment's assets and income test legislation was that it was retrospective. People who had made plans according to a known set of criteria were placed in a position, at least as at August of last year, in which there was a strong likelihood that that set of criteria was no longer to be valid. In other words, the conditions of eligibility for a pension were totally changed, or the change was threatened. It did not make any difference which it was, although perhaps in a way the fact that the change was threatened rather than implemented straightaway left many people up in the air about what their real position was. In fact people found or suspected that the plans they had made in 40 or 45 years of working life were for nought. Even worse, of course, people of pensionable age or within 12 months of pensionable age had a moratorium or a number of restrictions placed on what they could or could not do with existing assets from about the middle of 1983, and found that that moratorium was going to exist until 1 November 1984 or, presumably now, until the introduction of the new legislation.

So there is no doubt in my mind, any more than there is any doubt in the minds of many other senators and members, that many retired people are very worried indeed about what lies ahead of them; and that sort of emotional insecurity is something that no one should have to face in the last years of their lives. Those people currently on pensions, of course, have had added to the worry that they may lose the pension or have it reduced the unpalatable fact that, thanks to the Medicare sleight of hand, they will not receive in their November pension increase even a real consumer price index component increase, much less of course the promised 25 per cent of average weekly earnings that was dangled in front of them during the last election campaign.

I acknowledge a lot of what the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) had to say about the welfare cake having to go to the people most in need and about the fact that there were people who, under the existing system, through double dipping or some other form of managing their affairs, were able to get money that they did not really need. However, it seems to me that changes to the taxation system rather than changes to the social security system would be the way to cure that.

Having said that the welfare cake should go to those most in need, one would then be forced to the conclusion that, whilst the old system did not necessarily achieve that, an assets and income test system with exempt and non-exempt assets , one which shows a preference for one lifestyle over another, or one of the complexity of the Bill introduced into the House of Representatives in December of last year, would merely replace one set of anomalies with another and cause vast confusion in the minds of most elderly people. If the Government is to ensure financial and emotional security for retirees it has to make a realistic assessment of the needs of those people, that is, it has to make some sort of investigation of what people need when they retire and, of course, it should take into account both those with and without assets. Having done that, it should legislate accordingly.

In an attempt to come up with some assessment of this situation myself, I undertook, I admit in what must be a reasonably superficial way as I do not have by any means the resources that a government has, an investigation of the sorts of costs that would be faced by people from their time of retirement. I was interested in the amount of money a couple would need for an average retirement period of 14 1/2 years merely to maintain an average car and home throughout that period. I took figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics starting with a base age of 65 and adding to that an average life expectancy for both males and females of 14 1/2 years. I realise that the average female life span is more than that but for the purposes of the exercise I took 14 1/2 years from retirement as being the figure to work on.

In looking at the costs facing a married couple retiring at 65 and with an average life expectancy of 14 1/2 years, I had to obtain figures from a single source. Clearly they vary from State to State. I chose Queensland as the base State simply because it was about the most average of the States. I will not go into any great detail on why I picked Queensland. For house maintenance costs and car costs I used the Housing Commission of Queensland data and the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland respectively. I took house contents depreciation costs from the Australian Taxation Office. I have some very extensive details if any honourable senator would like to see them at some future stage; I do not have time to read them now.

However, what it amounted to was that average car costs for oil, petrol, tyres, registration, insurance and depreciation are in the vicinity of $2,171 per year. House content depreciation amounts to $730 per year. That takes into account items such as depreciation and replacement, if necessary, of things such as refrigerators, radios, various soft furnishings and so on. The actual maintenance on the house itself was taken on an average 12-square home which we priced at around $55,000. That is a modest home at a modest price in almost any part of Australia. The maintenance covers factors such as painting, replacing various elements of the home that are attached to it such as guttering, spouting , roofing, fencing and so on. That amounted to an additional $350 per year. All of that meant that over a 14 1/2-year period a retired couple had to have $47, 000 in a 10 per cent interest bearing account simply to be able to maintain their asset. At the end of that time they would not have a cent left in the account. I must stress that they would have been able to pay for nothing more than necessary maintenance of a modest home and car from that $47,000 over the specified 14 1/2-year period. It does not take into account day to day living costs such as food, health care requirements and so on, or allow for any leisure activities, unless one includes driving around in one's car looking at various caravan parks or a day trip to the beach. I also stress that if the Government wishes to subject all liquid assets for a couple over and above the allowable amount of $28,500 for a married couple to a 10 per cent assets test, the couple is going to have to have not $47,000 but $60,000. Again I must say that at the end of that 14 1/2-year period the couple would not have a cent left.

There is no doubt in my mind that wittingly or unwittingly the present Government has replaced one form of financial insecurity for retirees, that is a pension that was rapidly becoming far too low and which existed under the present Government, with another form of financial insecurity and added to it the burden of emotional insecurity as well because of the confusion surrounding the introduction of the proposed assets and income test legislation. This situation can be improved only if the Government is prepared to look at the real minimum needs of retirees, both those with and those without assets, and to come up in the future with pension eligibility criteria which acknowledge and provide for those needs. That means, of course, confronting the problem of indexation. Until the Government does this, until it comes up with a fair and equitable system for pensions-the sort of fair and equitable system that the Minister for Social Security has been talking about but which I do not believe is likely to be achieved under the proposed assets and income system any more than it is being achieved under the present system-and a system which has broad acceptability across the political and social spectrum then I think the insecurity that exists at the moment will continue to exist.

I will give honourable senators some quotes which are supposed to be the background of members of the Liberal Party opposite. Page 52 states:

Liberal platitudes about freedom for the individual have led to this whole matter of double-dipping, the stashing of assets and avoiding the income test and income tax. Honourable senators opposite stand condemned for their pandering to the greed of the wealthy who want to maintain their wealth. The Peacock-Sinclair Opposition are now busily engaged in locking themselves into positions which make them ready prey to the single-interest pressure groups .

I would have thought that if the so-called economic 'dries' of the Liberal Party had just one shred of intellectual honesty they would be the Government's strongest supporters in the campaign to reintroduce some sort of means test qualification for the old age pension.

Instead we have an Opposition which has continued to stir up trouble about the matter, misrepresenting our policies and confusing those who are likely to be affected and those who will not be affected despite the quite definite announcements by the Government. There should not have been misunderstanding. There was misunderstanding because of the confusion engendered by the Opposition causing a lack of security in the minds of those in retirement and those approaching retirement.

I despise its actions. It has deliberately upset those people least able to cope, most of whom will not actually be affected. The Liberals are responsible for the need to redirect income support away from the wealthy to the needy because of their actions in the past. The Opposition's legacy to the needy aged when it was in government was years of neglect which we are now having to deal with. I wish to give the Senate some examples of the things the Government has done to improve the position of the aged. The first point I want to make is that in February and March last year he led the people of Australia to believe that those people over 70 would not have their pensions abolished or a means test applied. Mr Hawke made it clear that there would be no tampering wtih the means test as such. The present Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), who is now not in the chamber, on 10 March, only two months ago, said:
Of around two million pensioners, fewer than 400,000 will lose some or all of the pension--

He said this as though it did not matter that some 400,000 people will lose some or all of the pension. A small number of people. We are now talking about hundreds of thousands of people.

Mr Hawke and the Australian Labor Party said that there would be no dabbling with superannuation. He said this a few days before the Government dabbled. There are 1.8 million Australians in superannuation schemes. We are not talking about airline pilots or the wealthy. They are the waterside workers, the iron workers, the clerks and the nurses-1.8 million of them-in private superannuation funds, 83 per cent of whom cannot take ordinary superannuation payments but must take lump sum superannuation payments. Senator Grimes has said that these are the wealthy people. No wonder that Mr Jennings of the Waterside Workers Federation-scarcely an airline pilots' union-said:
Hawke and his Government have ratted on the working class.

If we go a little further, as we are talking about the 'destruction of security in retirement for Australians', we find that Mr Cotter of the Clerical Officers Association-scarcely an airline pilots' association-said that this has:
. . . severely damaged the trust that had been placed in the Hawke Government.
Miss Haines, of the New South Wales Nurses Association-I take it that that is scarcely an airline pilots' association-said:
It's just mad. If Hawke's stupid enough to introduce it, he can take the consequences when the Government falls.
It is particularly disgusting from a Federal Labor Government---

These are the statements made by ordinary spokesmen and women from the ordinary unions. There are 1.8 million people involved; 120,000 people over 70 and at least 400,000 of the two million pensioners. No one knows which 400,000 it will be or whether it will be more. Certainly it will be at least 400,000, because Senator Grimes said so.

I will move further than that. Medicare, in its application, attacks everyone. It attacks all the people who are over retiring age-the 60-year old women and the 65-year-old males. Medicare forces two things. To the pensioners the Government says: 'We will fiddle the consumer price index and artificially debase your pensions. We will take away from a married couple $3.90 a week and from a single person $2.40 a week.' The destruction of security in retirement is demonstrable. Of course, Medicare goes to the very heart of it. The very same people are caught up in the indexing of excises on the petrol they must use in their humble lifestyle, and on tobacco and alcohol. Excise on all these things impinge upon those people. The commodities are snidely indexed so that it will not appear that any allowance has to be made.

Those who are not pensioners have to pay one per cent of their income as a Medicare levy, and they are not allowed gap insurance. I know of nowhere in the world where the freedom to insure oneself voluntarily is denied by law. It is the destruction of security in retirement. It is a deliberate act by this Government, its Ministers and members, to deny a person, whether a younger person or a retired person, the right to go to a health fund and to insure for the gap-the difference between what he gets back from Medicare and what the hospital or doctor charges. What an outrage that that should be so. Of course, the very failure to allow gap insurance is the destruction of security in retirement. People do not have the right freely to have the specialist of their choice and the hospital of their choice because their security is threatened.

It gets worse than that. The Government that said it would maintain the purchasing power of the retired person did nothing in its Budget to make an adjustment for inflation in the taxation threshold. The taxation threshold, from memory, is $4,533. The Government said in its policy statements: 'We will lift that to $5,000.' It did not do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not know how big the deficit was. You were not coming clean about it.

—Every one of the points I have made is a cold fact. Senator Walsh interjects, but the fact is that by not doing so he and his Government-he must take personal responsibility too-have forced tens of thousands of ordinary people who are outside the taxation threshold into paying tax, the destruction of security in retirement for Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is doing it patiently, step by step. 'Oh,' said the Hawke Labor Party 'put us in and we will alter the taxation scales. We will make 12 scales so that people on low incomes will not pay as much tax.' Nothing was done. By the erosion of inflation people pay more, not less. Those in retirement on meagre incomes have experienced the destruction of security in retirement.

I will take it one step further. The Labor Party said: 'Put us in and we will raise the percentage the pension bears to the average weekly wage from the existing 22 per cent to 25 per cent.' Not a move has been made. The Government intends to go to the people at the end of this year. It will not have done anything, in 90 to 95 per cent of the life of this Parliament, on any of those matters. Whatever it may pretend to do in the Budget will not be carried out in the ordinary lifetime of this Parliament. None of the alterations to the taxation scales will be made. The tax threshold will not be lifted. The pension will not move to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. No doubt there will be some rhetoric in the Budget. If the Government were to take into account the adjustment of the pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and the robbery of the Medicare fiddle, it would not be a matter of lifting the pension by $2.40 a week for a single person or $3.90 for a married couple. It would have to add another $5 to compensate. A gesture will be made, certainly, and a claim will be made that the Government has done something in dollars to lift things, but the reality will be that the Government will have participated in the destruction of security in retirement.

First of all, 120,000 people over 70 will be affected. The assets test will affect at least 400,000 people. Taxation of lump sum superannuation payments will affect 1.8 million people. Medicare will affect the 2 million people in retirement. There has been an attack on the threshold of the tax scale.

The Government's promises have failed. There has been a blatant destruction of people's living standards. Now there is the movement, through the taxation on lump sum superannuation payments and the assets test, to venture on a path of confiscation of savings, nothing less. Taxation on lump sum superannuation payments is in fact the compulsory confiscation of savings.

What nonsense it is for a Minister to say that there is no retrospectivity. Those 1.8 million people who entered into a superannuation scheme did so in the knowledge and belief that upon their retirement their savings would attract only 5 per cent taxation when paid in lump sums. That was their understanding. The journey for some of them has been 20 years, for others it has been 30. They entered into the scheme with that belief. To say there is no retrospectivity because their contributions in the past will not be touched and the Government will tax only their contributions in the future is an illusion. The Government is saying that people cannot take advantage of the scheme in to which they entered for the whole of their working lives; they can take advantage of it for only part of their working lives and then a different one will be forced upon them.

If there is one fundamental in this world it is that people strive to retain their dignity if they can be encouraged into voluntary providence by incentives. The Minister for Social Security attacked the incentive taxation allowance to superannuants. He attacked the allowances to the companies that provide superannuation. He said that 5 per cent is not enough for people to pay at the end. If a system of providence can be created in this country which enables people to save and invest, God bless that system.

The aim of the present system-this has been repeated today by Senator Grimes-is to force people into purchasing an annuity. In other words, they must surrender their capital and take a weekly pension. He is determined, as all socialists are , to institutionalise savings. No one will be allowed to invest where he wants to invest. The great investment institutions will make those decisions and nobody else. People will have to purchase annuities with their savings. In future it will not be the decision of parents to save during their lifetimes, pay off their mortgages upon retirement, set up little businesses, give something to their children to support them, or even, in an old-fashioned way, when they die leave a little for their children. Not at all. The Labor scheme is to get at the very heart of people's capital and confiscate it. That is the basis of the scheme.

The Labor Government cannot stop at taxing lump sum superannuation payments. It has to impose, step by step, a capital gains tax on every individual who does not use an orthodox scheme but some other form of capital accretion. A simple thing for a person to do, instead of paying superannuation week by week, is to buy a large elaborate home and sweat to pay it off over a lifetime so that it has a large resale value. Of course, that cannot be resisted. In the end the socialist Government will get its hot and clammy hands on it as a capital gain. There is no doubt in the world that once a government says: 'We will not let people become voluntarily provident and acquire capital for whatever purpose', it is imposing a capital gains tax. Of course, the next step is the reinstitution of probate. Patently, what has happened is that, demonstrably on at least six or seven fronts, there has been a massive attack upon the security of all retired people in Australia. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the Government defends a quite remarkable topic for debate: The destruction of security in retirement for Australians by the Hawke Labor Government. SPEECH.PARA: Into this environment came the Labor Government. Before Senator Messner leaves the chamber, I think it is important, for the record, to welcome him back from overseas. It is not possible to gaze at your navel while looking up.

On reflection we must surely question the extent to which this rising expenditure is economically and socially productive, and whether it meets genuine social need. So much of government spending goes to people who demonstrably do not need government assistance.

The government--
that is, the then Liberal Government-
is concerned that . . . Income rigging practices are circumventing the intent of the laws and throwing undue burdens on taxpayers generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The Peacock-Sinclair Opposition are now busily engaged in locking themselves into positions which make them ready prey to the single-interest pressure groups .

Apart from the Medicare contribution, inflation is falling anyhow, although it still remains high and this Government still has much work to do. I assure the Opposition that it will continue to do it. TALK.START.PARA: —Seven and a half years of Fraser.

—Exactly, as Senator Sibraa says, seven and a half years of Fraser. The other consequence of unemployment is a huge payout of unemployment benefit. SPEECH.PARA: It is within the constraints of a Budget deficit, of demands on social security and the Government Treasury coffers, and of a falling amount of money coming into the coffers because of the increasing level of unemployment and inflation rate, that this Government set about its proposals for security for people in retirement. It has already made quite some gains. But as I say, the Opposition argues the issue as though it were a single issue. It does not deal with those other very important economic measurements that will enormously affect what the Government can do. One of the Government's steps was to attempt some redistribution of the money that can be distributed to pensioners. It has proposed the taxation of lump sums of superannuation. The legislation is not yet before the House, but the argument is certainly under consideration. In fact, although the Opposition says it is a terrible thing, any number of people in the community admit the rightness of the argument that those people on smaller superannuation do not need to be disadvantaged compared with those people who take huge lump sum superannuation payments. Another change that the Government has made has been to reduce the age pension for people over 70 years of age.
