The Government has tackled that as a matter of serious consideration. Any number of pensioner groups to which I and other Government members have spoken do not hear serious complaints from pensioner groups. We have to realise that some 85 per cent of pensioners are very accepting of the changes that are occurring because those 85 per cent of pensioners have no means other than the pension. Pensioners without any other means are saying that they are very grateful and accepting of the Government's proposed changes to redistribute some of the pension dollar from people who have other means besides the pension to pensioners most in need.

It is quite silly of Senator Messner to come in here and to claim that we have reduced the security of Australian people in retirement. That is not true. We have reduced some of the income of those who can well afford a reduction. Senator Messner is one of those who have been going around reducing security. He has been arguing lots of nonsense in all sorts of places and whipping up all sorts of steam and heat but avoiding the facts like mad. If he wants to tackle the facts he might take on Senator Grimes in a proper debate. He could argue the Opposition's policy with Senator Grimes. But he cannot do that because the Opposition does not have a policy. It is Senator Messner and his colleagues who have been provoking the unrest around the country.

We have heard some complaints about the consumer price index artificially affecting pensions by seemingly being reduced, yet expenditure not being reduced . In the short term there is no doubt that there will be some of that effect. However the Government is moving very quickly to address the problem, of the direct effect on pensioners. It has already made some effort to do so by increasing the pension and indexing it six-monthly. But at the same time the fall in the consumer price index means that, inflation being down, there will be less push for wages. There will be less of an increase in the costs of services, of fruit and vegetables and of the maintenance of supports in the community. All of the gains from a falling consumer price index-that is, from a falling inflation rate-will be of benefit to pensioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —You really misunderstand the point, don't you?

—I understand the point very well. Senator Messner fails to see a pluralist approach to these arguments. He has a single-minded approach and a single issue approach to a very complex issue. If he really wants to follow up this issue, which he says is a matter of seriousness for the Australian people, he should take on the challenge of Senator Grimes, the Minister, who has asked for a considered debate on the topic, for a policy against his policy, not carping complaints about Government policy. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Item No. 3 of today's list of papers is a Government response to the report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the Horn of Africa. It would be appropriate for the text of such a statement to be incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave for the statement to be so incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I commend the Committee for the preparation of this report. It documents many important matters concerning the recent use of aid in the countries of the Horn of Africa. The report has been referred by the Committee to the Jackson Aid Review for its consideration of the issues raised in the broader context of Australia's global aid policy. The primary focus of the report concerns allegations about corruption, misuse and mismanagement of humanitarian aid, from several donor sources, in the Horn of Africa. In responding, I propose to similarly confine my remarks to these specific issues.

Matters relating to broader policy questions, I believe, should be taken up in the context of consideration of the recommendations of the Jackson review. Development assistance is an important part of Australia's bilateral relations with countries in the Horn of Africa, particularly Ethiopia and Somalia. Both these countries have low per capita income and are also net importers of food. Therefore, there is a very important role to be played by aid in assisting the development process in these countries. However, I place very great importance on the efficient and effective use of the Australian taxpayers' money in the provision of overseas aid and claims that our aid is being misused need to be treated very seriously. I welcome the efforts of the Joint Committee to investigate such allegations in regard to the countries of the Horn of Africa and accept its findings. I am pleased that the Committee was able to convey its comments on these matters and also with respect to Australia's aid monitoring capacities in that region of Africa to the Jackson review.

Food aid is the principal component of our aid to the Horn and I would like now to comment specifically on the Committee's findings on this type of aid. The Chairman of the Joint Committee, the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison), in presenting the Committee's report to the House on 1 March 1984, made reference to Australian food aid and drew attention to page 114 of the report which notes 'Australia's food aid contributions have increased significantly over the years. It is necessary on humanitarian grounds in view of the recent droughts and continuing refugee problem that relief aid be provided. Relief aid is justified where there is an urgent problem requiring attention, but its usefulness is only short-term'.

The Chairman also drew attention to the Committee's finding that 'there is a danger in the long-term provision of food aid only. Once established, unless there is potential or incentive for recipients of aid to produce their own food, aid becomes self-perpetuating and is very difficult to cut off'. I agree with this viewpoint.

I think it is worth noting a few points about Australian food aid and its use as a development tool. All recipients of Australian food aid are food deficit countries and most are also low income countries with limited capacity to import food to feed their populations. Even under circumstances where there is a concerted effort by the country to eliminate the root causes of food insecurity, many of Australia's food aid recipients will have a continuning need for food aid for some time. Australia, as a major food producer and exporter will continue to receive requests to provide food aid to these countries and there will be a continuing need for Australia to respond, particularly to emergency situations.

In those cases where Australian food aid is used in other than emergency feeding situations, we are endeavouring to improve its development impact. Our preference is that the food aid be used directly as food for work in development projects. Where the food is sold we require, wherever feasible, that it be sold at cost plus freight prices in order to decrease the disincentive effects of subsidised food sales on local food producers. The funds generated from the sale are then directed to deveolopment projects, preferably food security projects, in the recipient country.

As I have already noted, claims have been made about the misuse of aid from several donor sources in the Horn countries, namely misappropriation of food aid ; food aid not reaching those in need; inadequate monitoring and the ineffectiveness of long term relief aid. In this regard honourable members may be interested to know the arrangements for this year's Australian food aid program to Ethiopia and Somalia. In the 1983-84 financial year Australia will provide Ethiopia with 16000 tonnes of wheat.

11,600 tonnes of this wheat will be used in a food for work development project involving land reclamation and reafforestation. This project is an extension of a similar successful world food programme project and aims to restore degraded land to productivity. The World Food Programme has been contracted to monitor and supervise the use of this food and it is expected that the project will help to eliminate Ethiopia's chronic food shortage situation. The remaining 4,400 tonnes of wheat is to be used in projects more immediately associated with the current emergency. These projects will have developmental as well as purely relief components.

It has been decided after consultation with the Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission that the food will go through the counterpart organisations of Australian non-government organisations operating in Ethiopia. In addition to the 16,000 tonnes of wheat going directly to Ethiopia I have for the first time this year approved a food aid gift to three Australian non- government organisations for use by the Eritrean Relief Association in Eritrea. This assistance, which comprises 1,000 tonnes of wheat, 20 tonnes of high protein biscuits and 20 tonnes of whole milk powder, is provided on a humanitarian basis to assist those people suffering from drought and conflict in areas not controlled by the Government of Ethiopia. A cash contribution of $300, 000 has also been made through Australian NGOs for other projects of the Eritrean Relief Association to benefit disaster and drought affected people.

In Somalia, Australia has been supporting an international effort to assist some 500,000 to 700,000 refugees resulting from the conflict between Ethiopia and Somalia. In 1983-84, we will provide 3,000 tonnes of flour, 3,000 tonnes of rice and 100 tonnes of high protein biscuits. These commodities have been requested by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and their use will be supervised by the World Food Programme. Australia has encouraged UNHCR to use this food in supporting long-term solutions to the resettlement of these refugees rather than relying on continuing relief support. We understand that the Government of Somalia has recently agreed to the resettlement of these refugees in Somalia and are planning development projects for this purpose.

In addition to this support for refugees, I have also approved a further gift of 1,000 tonnes of wheat to Somalia. The honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), who spoke on the need for self help projects when the Committee's report was tabled in the House, will be interested to know that this wheat will be sold in Somalia at cost plus freight prices with the proceeds being directed to the community aid abroad primary health care project to which he referred and which was recommended as worthy of support by the Committee. This project is funded by the Australian Government and will involve an expenditure of approximately $3m over five years. In concluding, I would like to again welcome the Committee's report and the discussion it has encouraged concerning the effective utilisation of overseas aid resources in a part of the globe little known by the Australian community. I am particularly pleased that the Committee was able to complete the report in time for it to be referred to the Jackson review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The fifteenth report by the Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications is an interesting document. When one reads the report the ongoing nature of the work, despite the slight wind down in the number of migrants coming to Australia , becomes evident. The problems that the Committee is faced with do not seem to decrease but rather to increase over the years. Of course, the Committee on Overseas Professional Qualifications tends to concern itself with the professions: Dentistry, engineering, medicine, pharmacy and the like. However, a very large range of problems is currently emerging in the various trades which tend to come under State regulations and which, I think, are increasingly creating difficulties for many people. I refer to such trades as bricklaying. Bricklayers coming, for example, from South Africa have difficulties with employment in Australia because of the difference between the trade qualifications which are required in Australia and in South Africa.

One case I have in mind has resulted in an extraordinary catch-22 situation. Unless a migrant has worked for 12 months he or she is not allowed to get a ticket which entitles him or her to work. He or she cannot work unless he or she has that ticket, yet he or she is not allowed to get a ticket until he or she has worked for 12 months. Of course, that absurdity within the professions led to the establishment of this Committee, which has worked so well over the 15 or 16 years it has been established.

One item of this report which I think is extremely interesting is the discussion revolving around the multiple choice questions which must be answered by applicants in the various professions in overseas embassies and their applicability to Australia. One of the major difficulties in this area has always been the non-acceptance within the professions of those multiple choice questions and the generation of a sufficient data bank of those questions to enable the examinations that are taken in that area to be sufficiently varied so as not to allow cribbing or even not to allow, as is currently the case in some of those professional areas, the students who are going to take them the chance to look at previous questions in the area so that they may prepare themselves for the examination, as is only fair. It is of interest, however, that despite that, the professions of physiotherapy, pharmacy, dentistry, medicine, nursing, occupational therapy and veterinary science have now been able to generate sufficient of those to enable this to take place. That has been of extreme benefit to many of the migrants coming to Australia in easing the way for the acceptance of their professional qualifications and hence in easing the way for them to again work in the Australian community, work which is often of the sort that Australia needs and requires from its migrants.

Obviously the Committee will continue in its work. I hope that it will provide, not only in the area of professional qualifications but also in other areas, the guidelines which it so obviously is now capable of generating, so that the rather haphazard operation in areas outside the professions might be dealt with in the extremely competent way that the professions are being dealt with.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON PRICES AND INCOMES POLICY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I should like to make a number of preliminary statements. I make them without having had the benefit of a study of the report and the statement, but I shall have an opportunity to do that before the debate on this matter is resumed. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that we are here dealing with one of the really critical areas of policy which goes to the question of employment and the future of employment in Australia. There is a sense about that the employment position has eased and that there has been a rise in employment, with some of it being in the private sector and the bulk of it being in the sector which is affected by government, the government sector. But it remains true that unemployment in Australia is still high, and that there are a very large number of economic predictions that unemployment will worsen.

I recall that one of the more recent public statements to that effect was the submission of the Merchant Bankers Association to the Government's advisory body , the Economic Planning Advisory Council, when the Association suggested that, given current policies, there is likely to be an unemployment rate of about 11.6 per cent in 1986. Given the sorts of patterns that we have at present, that indicates a situation which all of us would regard as totally unsatisfactory and , in particular, when one applies it to youth unemployment, which is often twice as high as the general rate of unemployment which is demonstrated, obviously we face a very significant, severe and continuing social problem.

There is a great deal of politics in this debate. We are in an election year, we are told, and of course the Government makes the most of the positive factors to which it can point since it came to office. But I think that even Government spokesmen on occasions are prepared to admit that there are continuing difficulties. I have been struck by the caution that Senator Button, for example , has shown about what the future holds in any comments that he has made on employment. Even Mr Dawkins, on 13 March, made a statement which bears out the sort of caution that has been evidenced in this chamber. On the national Today show, Mr Dawkins was asked:
Do you agree with Mr Keating's view that our economic recovery is patchy?
Mr Dawkins said:

I think it is certainly true in the point that he was particularly emphasising, that the recovery up to this point has been very largely due to a number of one- off factors, not only the breaking of the drought but the particular stimulus that the Government has been able to give the economy in such areas as housing and so on, and that that kind of increased activity will have to be overtaken in the future by private investment pick-up if the recovery is going to continue and endure over the years to come.

Again, we have had debate in this place about the predictions about private investment. It has fallen very steeply this year, in both manufacturing and mining. It is thought that there may be a very small recovery in manufacturing next year, but there is a forecast of a continuing decline in the mining sector. A number of factors give rise to a great deal of concern. Capital investment is down. It is likely to continue to go down or, at best, to remain in its extremely subdued situation.

All of the concerns which have been expressed by the Government about the need for greater capital investment if we are to get recovery and to maintain growth in employment are shared by the Opposition. As I have said, it is a debate which tends to become highly charged and very political because of the fact that we are in an election year. I just wish, in these preliminary comments on the prices and incomes policy, to remind the Senate that we are looking at policy which is being operated in the context of serious risks being present in a situation in which there may well be economic decline ahead, and in which the Opposition has the deepest possible reservations about the correctness of the Government's prices and incomes policy. We say that simply because there is so much evidence about that notwithstanding the rise in employment over recent months, a rise that we very much welcome, there are very great risks ahead, and we think that the policies that the Government is pursuing in this area are not appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report by the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes is the second progress report on the Government's initiatives . That Advisory Committee is a tripartite body, consistent with the view of this Government that all sectors of industry should be playing a key role in advising the Government and being consulted on the management of its central policies. As has been said, the prices and incomes accord, the Australian Labor Party- Australian Council of Trade Unions accord, is the linchpin of the Government's economic policy. This report is, therefore, vital in providing a means of assessing how the policy is proceeding and the soundness of the initiative in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pleasing that there are 100 pages of initiatives reported in this report that cover all aspects of what constitute living standards. It is further pleasing that on 4 May, when the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, tabled this report in the House of Representatives, he was able to conclude by putting down a statement which finished with this paragraph:

Australia can now be said to be at the forefront of economic policy development with an economic policy which is performing with the essential dual function of promoting short term recovery and providing the basis for sustained long term growth.
That is a fair summary of what the policy has thus far been able to achieve.

Many aspects are coverned in this report, but I shall concentrate on just one of them-the question of wages policy. What this Government has been able to achieve in wages policy is revolutionary. In the past, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has played a central role in wages, and under the mechanisms of that Commission trade unions were encouraged to file ambit claims, claims which asked for the sky in the hope that what would be settled would be something closer to the earth. In the negotiations which followed the ambit claims, unions were encouraged, knowing that there was no regulatory authority or no control or surveillance over prices or taxes, or a social wage, to try to maximise their bargaining power in the work place, to go for as much as they possibly could and to argue an extreme case before the Commission, asking the Commission, with the wisdom of Solomon, to choose the right course.

The prices and incomes policy has changed wages policy to the extent that now workers in the community can look forward with great certainty to wages moving according to movements in the consumer price index. The Government was able last year to persuade the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to adopt that as its central approach to wage fixation, and so far wages have moved in that way. This has meant that the uncertainty about the economic future for wage and salary earners has been removed. They know that if prices move their wages will move to compensate. At long last the union movement in this country can take its eyes off the paper chase after artificial wages that are eroded by price increases or are cut back by the tax claw-back, because now workers understand that they have a government with which they can negotiate and, instead of chasing wages, for the first time they can talk about the matter that really concerns them-living standards. Under the accord living standards are identified as being made up of wages, taxes, prices and the social wage provided by the Government.

On all of those fronts certainty has been given to wage and salary earners, which certainty, in my view, lies at the foot of the statistics on strike activity over the last 12 months in this country. In the first year of the Labor Government, 1983, strikes fell by 25 per cent over 1982 and in January strikes were at a six-year low. That has to be contrasted absolutely, I believe, with the policy of the Opposition, which would increase inflation by causing a wage blow-out and encouraging expansion in that area. Consistent with our wages policy, inflation has come down and unemployment figures have dropped. I think that stands as an enduring testimony to the effectiveness of the prices and incomes policy and I believe that in the longer term the policy will convince even the Opposition which is alone in Australia at this time in not supporting the approach.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and of the Sub- Committee on Middle Eastern and African Affairs, of which I was Chairman, appreciate the way in which the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has responded on behalf of the Government to the report on Australian aid to the Horn of Africa.

As the Minister said, it was the Committee's intention that the report be considered by the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program. One of the problems of Australia's aid has been that of setting priorities. These include the choices that have to be made between development assistance and emergency relief, between aid to our immediate region in South East Asia and the Pacific and countries further away from Australia, including Africa, and between multilateral aid and bilaterial aid. It was clear to the Committee that, because of its narrow focus on the Horn of Africa, it could not properly address these problems in the context of our overall aid program and that the Jackson Committee was in the best position to do so. One particularly welcome part of the Minister's speech is his reference to increased Australian aid to the Eritrean Relief Association. In its report the Committee documented the plight of the drought smitten and war affected population of Eritrea and noted that people who lived in areas not under Ethiopian Government control were not receiving adequate assistance.

The Committee recommended that the Australian Government should determine the best method of providing food and medical aid to Eritrea and Eritrean refugees through sources other than the Ethiopian Government, where aid channelled through the Ethiopian Government cannot be provided to those in the greatest need. The decision to provide 1,000 tonnes of wheat, 20 tonnes of high protein biscuits and 20 tonnes of whole milk powder, together with $300,000 in cash contributed to the Eritrean Relief Association, deserves all our support.

Another welcome development is the strong support the Government is giving to the Community Aid Abroad self-help primary health care program in Somalia. I am also impressed with the Government's acknowledgment of the valuable work carried out by non-government aid organisations generally in the region. As the Minister commented, the Committee addressed in detail the allegations that have been made in relation to the misuse and misappropriation of aid in Ethiopia. In times of relative economic difficulty in our own country it is sometimes a difficult job to convince the electorate that we should maintain a sizable overseas aid program. It is therefore heartening to see the emphasis placed by the Minister on the efficient use of taxpayers' money in the provision of overseas aid. Allegations of misuse and misappropriation of aid in Ethiopia have continued in the British Press since the Committee tabled its report last year, and the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and the Department of Foreign Affairs will have to continue to address this issue. It is an issue that worried the Committee; it is an issue that is very hard to monitor.

Other matters referred to by the Minister are in line with the thrust of the Committee's report. The Committee expressed concern about the relief mentality that builds up among food aid recipients. The emphasis given to food for work projects involving land reclamation and reafforestation projects and decisions to sell food, where feasible, at cost plus freight prices in order to decrease the disincentive effects of subsidised sales on local food producers go some way to meeting the Committee's concerns.

The Minister is to be commended for his early reply to the Committee's report and the Government is also to be commended for setting up the Jackson Committee to review Australia's aid program. The seriousness with which this Government is addressing aid and developmental issues and its determination to get value for the taxpayer's dollar is a welcome contrast to the ad hockery which characterised the previous Government's approach. We hope that the Committee's final report, which is the third in a series on the Horn of Africa, will be tabled in the Parliament in the near future. I am hopeful that at that stage the Goverment will be able to provide for a full debate, not only on that report but also on the two previous reports the Committee has put down, so that the Senate can spend some time-and not just the five minutes that are allowed to us on the presentation of papers-debating what is a serious issue.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be opposing the Insurance Contracts Bill 1983 and moving the amendments which have been circulated. I think it would be interesting to look at the history of this Bill. It was introduced on 1 December 1983. The Government set it down for the second reading debate during March 1984 and at the Opposition's request it was adjourned until May. In April 1984 Government representatives of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) met with the Insurance Council of Australia Ltd to discuss certain amendments. Following those discussions the Government intimated that amendments would be made, but it would not indicate the precise nature of the changes it was contemplating. Finally, on Monday, 30 April 1984, 59 amendments were drafted and presented to the Opposition. The revised draft plus the explanatory memo was given to the Opposition on a confidential basis but consultation with industry groups was not allowed until 10 a.m. last Tuesday. Today three more amendments have come through. With all this conglomeration there is apparently no thought yet of providing a retyped consolidated Bill. So we must stagger on with this legislation and all the bits and pieces.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition wishes to make it known that it gives credit to the Government and to the Attorney-General for arranging the interviews and having the discussions with the industry. It is pleasing that they called for the submissions and that they took as much notice of them as they did. One has only to look at the nature of the amendments and the stage they have reached to realise what an impossible mess we would have been in had the Government proceeded with the legislation at the time that it intended to do so, in March this year. Had that been the case the Bill would have been passed already. What a mess it would have been. Australia, like any other country, rests very heavily on the nature of its reserves and resources generally, and its ability to meet contingencies that will arise in the future. That applies to insurance as it does to work, superannuation, pensions and everything else. Insurance is the way in which we look forward to safeguarding for these future contingencies. In the years ahead it will be necessary that Australia be able to depend more and more on the reserves it establishes now. We need to ensure that our reserves are operated in a careful and appropriate manner.

I suppose that I have had an association with insurance in one way or another for something over 30 years. I think it pays us all to remember that insurance, at all levels, is a contract, and that a contract requires two sides. Put simply , both parties are entitled to the benefits and both sides are entitled to safeguarding the obligations. I think that point is where I come into difficulty with this legislation. In Australia we have a situation where there is both private insurance and Government insurance. It is fair to say, as one would expect, that the Government has failed really to demonstrate at any point that it can operate either more efficiently or more profitably than the private sector, wherever they might be in competition. This brings me back to the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System which was adamant that the most efficient way to organise economic activity is through a competitive market system which is subject to a minimum of regulation and government intervention. We do not seem to learn from these statements but go on intervening more and more. Of course, totally free markets, at times, are imperfect. I can assure the Senate, however, that totally regulated markets are almost invariably imperfect.

As I have said before insurance is a two-party operation; the insurer and the insured. As we tend to look at alterations to the system, we have a duty to see that the emphasis is placed on both parties and not on just one, as a scapegoat. Clearly consumers should suffer penalties as well as insurers, and probably more than insurers. I see the legislation as being an absolute interventionist monument. To me it is counter productive, unwarranted, unjustifiable and expensive. It is incorrectly founded and it will certainly be divisive.

The Law Reform Commission suddenly bought into this argument, a participation which was never sought by industry. It has never been justified. Clearly it was a whim of Mr Justice Kirby who has never taken any notice of what the companies felt about that. In the report Mr Justice Kirby states that he interviewed and had discussions with the industry. As I understand it, it was an extremely one- sided discussion; he took no notice of the industry whatsoever and clearly, went away and wrote up what he intended to carry on with in years ahead. I think that the figures that are available speak for themselves. The records show that in the test period, 1976-77, 2.08 per cent of all claims were rejected. In other words, 98 per cent of all claims were accepted and paid. Some 78 per cent of the claims that were rejected were rejected because the insurance contract was not even in relation to the claims made. In other words, 0.58 of one per cent of claims were contested by the insurers. When we consider the sorts of frauds such as arson, misrepresentation and so on concerning insurance, 0.58 of one per cent is a very small proportion. I cannot understand why it would be thought necessary to mess up the whole system for the purpose of trying to cover 0.58 of one per cent of claims over which there may have been some disagreement. The fact that 0.58 per cent of claims was held to be reasonable does not indicate that in all those cases the insurance companies were wrong; far from it. That is the basis on which the Government has decided to make all the alterations through the Insurance Contracts Bill 1983.

The other thing that I find completely impossible is that without any discussions and negotiations with the States we are now setting up an insurance system which, for the first time in history, will create two entirely individual classes of business-State insurance and non-State insurance. We will have two insurance laws, two lots of costs, two interpretations of claims and two contracts. Everybody will be very happy, I am sure. It is important to remember that over a third-normally regarded as between 36 per cent and 40 per cent-of this sort of insurance is undertaken with State insurers, the balance being with private companies. Is this sort of mess what the legislation seeks to impose? Will we, as private individuals, know what the differences are between the State insurers and the private insurer? Who will regulate the costs between the two insurers? Who will see that the contracts are similar, or that the claims are dealt with in a like or similar manner?

Of course, although 36 per cent to 40 per cent of all insurance in Australia is done through State insurers, this Bill will not apply to that. In no way will this Bill apply. Will we just rely on the States saying: 'We will follow you. We believe what you are doing is right'? Or are we just going to hope that it is right? I am not sure whether the drafters and the instigators of the legislation believe that it is just going to happen, because I am fairly sure that it is not . I believe there is a long way to go in getting the two types of insurers to adopt a similar attitude.

For the private insurers there will now be considerably greater bureacracy. There will be considerably more form filling and higher costs, and higher costs mean higher premiums. Higher premiums mean that more people in the community will insure less. I am not sure that that is what we need. I am not sure that that is what we should be trying to encourage. I believe it is desirable that we should be encouraging people to seek better insurance. I do not like the thought of having people covered less against the risks that will follow. However, that is the obvious corollary with rising costs.

I am fascinated by fraud, as I am sure is Senator Evans. We are now talking about introducing legislation which will make fraud legal. We are also going to have small fraud and partial fraud, even non-criminal fraud. We are going to have acceptable admitted fraud and fraud condoned, even insurance recovery of admitted fraud claims. I find this absolutely extraordinary. I do not know of anything which could do more to encourage fraudulent practices. It is a case of saying: 'Well, we can try with a little bit of fraud in the first place and if we get away with it we will carry on'. I ask you! Are we trying to protect the 99.42 per cent of insurers whose claims were made and paid without argument, or are we going to do all this just to try to protect the 0.58 per cent of insurers who had arguments about their claims? All this can only make insurance more expensive and less affordable; there will be less cover and more risk.

Why are we seeking to protect the people who, on the wording of the Bill, seek to induce some element of fraud? Is it the policy of the Government to look after the crooks in the insurance game? I am sure I do see it as being so. I do not think that we should be giving any people who endeavour fradulently to obtain money any protection of any description. I do not see that it is reasonable to ignore the difference that exists between domestic and commercial insurance. From discussions that I have had with the insurance people, they do not understand that either. I do not see why the Government has refused to accept that there is this sort of difference. I applaud the deletion of the ridiculous reference to 'the reasonable man'. I thank Senator Evans that we have at least got that far because it is very hard in a place like this to assess- apart from him and me!-what 'reasonable man' involves.

Insurance needs tighter legislation in order to cope with fraud and, in particular, arson. The Insurance Contracts Bill does not take any steps of any sort to eliminate fraud at any level. It is my intention to speak in the near future on arson. Without making the speech now, I will say that the best estimate of what arson is costing in Australia at present is about $820m a year. With an enormous loss and cost in the community of that level it appears to me far more appropriate to devote our time to trying to protect people from that kind of loss. It is also interesting to note that the payment of $820m a year for arson doubles the cost of all fire and householder insurance in Australia. I believe it would have been far more appropriate to try to eliminate that $820m crime. We should be ensuring that the insurers of Australia are able to halve the cost of their insurance. This legislation is really nothing more than nuisance legislation. It totally ignores the real problems of insurance and makes crime easier.

I am also interested to see the incorporation of the standard contract. Really, it makes me laugh because in the days when I was involved in insurance we had an insurance tariff and we used standard contracts. The only reason that we do not use standard contracts now is that that other great architect of interference, the Trade Practices Act, outlawed it as a restraint of trade. As soon as we get it outlawed, sure enough, here comes Mr Justice Kirby saying: 'We need a standard contract; we want one back again'. I cannot see that the insurance industry will object to having the standard contract back because it has worked with standard contracts for a lot longer than it has worked without them. This is a typical case of government interference and intervention by people who do not really understand-it takes, the medal. I am interested to see whose move it will be now. I am not sure whether the trade practices people will come in and override the Law Reform Commission and the legislation or vice versa, but I guess the matter has not finished here. We will see what occurs as the tug of war proceeds.

I cannot see that the Bill in its present form is necessary or desirable in any way. It does nothing to fight the real problems of insurance; it makes it more attractive for crooks to explore and engage in fraud; it makes it more expensive for small insurers; and it creates this extraordinary division between State and private insurers. I oppose the Bill. At the appropriate time I will introduce amendments on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we all acknowledge-the Government, the Opposition, people in the industry and insurers-that the Government has indeed had the opportunity of getting a wide range of input into its proposed legislation, the Insurance Contracts Bill. With that knowledge it is very disturbing to find that in the short space of time since the Bill was presented to the Senate 59 amendments have been presented. As late as today, on our desks this afernoon, were some further amendments. I think that reflects the ad hoc attitude this Government takes towards legislation. It reflects the fact that it does not really listen and does not properly analyse what it receives. It does not consider the impact that it will have on the insurers or the insurance industry. However, at the midnight hour, one minute to midnight, along comes a whole host of amendments. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) acknowledges that we are now consulting people and that is why we are making the amendments. I submit that the Government should have considered these matters much earlier in the piece. I believe the Government still has an incomplete and very unsatisfactory Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: When this Government came to power there were a lot of lofty notions of how it would protect the consumer. It was going to do that despite all the trenchant opposition from established and vested interests. But what do we find? We find that most of these 59 amendments represent a buckling under. If we look at it from the ordinary consumer's point of view, the Government has let the consumer down. The Government came in with lofty ideals and the consumers applauded it but when the test came, yes, it consulted; it buckled under pressure. From a consumer's point of view, it is most disappointing to see a government with such lofty ideals cave in to this sort of last minute pressure. This Government says that it determined to stand for what it believes in-looking after the small man- but when the test comes the Government buckles under. What has happened to the pension test? The Government has changed its mind. The pensions test has been put in a state of abeyance. I am surprised that we have this Bill before us today. I thought it might have been put on the back burner, as has the assets test and the final treatment of lump sum superannuation payments.

If the Government is dinkum I presume that, within a short time, we will see another spate of amendments. Even in my own humble way I can see that some changes are needed as far as the ordinary person is concerned. I think the provisions in the area of solvency are quite inadequate. Therefore, I take this opportunity of welcoming the appointment of Mr Warren Tickle as the new Insurance Commissioner. Even the ICA Bulletin of 8 March 1984 acknowledges that he will be an asset to industry. I was particularly interested in his comments. The article in the ICA Bulletin states:
He suggested that any measures designed to strengthen the solvency margins should be welcomed and supported but at the same time he is a firm believer in the industry being self regulatory.
From the outset Mr Tickle was anxious to assure us he would consult closely with industry and would welcome input from ICA and its member companies.

I think that is a nice approach. This man has had experience in working for Sun Alliance Insurance Ltd, a prominent company, university work and teaching. It appears to me that he is eminently qualified and has the right approach to tackle this job.

Let us look at the 59 amendments to this legislation. I apologise that I have not had an opportunity of examining the impact of the amendments which were introduced this afternoon. I do not know how the Government expects us to appreciate what is involved when it brings this debate on at such short notice and under these circumstances. As I have said, most of these amendments appear to be designed to assist the insurer and not the insured. Who is looking after the so-called consumer interests? Again, the Australian Labor Party, in its amendments, appears to have fallen from its lofty rhetoric about the Bill being a Bill designed to give real help to small policy holders.

It is my understanding that, ironically, before business could be placed with an overseas insurance company a client had to be informed of this before the contract was entered into. That was the previous situation. Alas, as a result of at least one of these amendments what I think is a pretty vital provision is being removed. Let us imagine that I am a small policy holder and know nothing about insurance and along comes an insurance agent representing a South American insurance company in Buenos Aires. He could be the only representative of that company visiting my State. He could knock on my door and say: 'I represent a beaut insurance company. Will you take out this policy?' But now he does not have to tell the policy holder that his head office is in South America or Timbuktu. What a let down for ordinary policy holders! This is one of the Government's amendments. I thought the Government was trying to help the small policy holder. As I understand it, the Government's amendment removes this requirement. Unbeknown to an Australian policy holder, a policy could be effectively written by a person who is representing a company anywhere in the world. But what happens when a claim is made? Will the policy holder be able to find this man who has been knocking on his door? No. The policy holder will have to look at the small print.

I have a fear of what could be put in the regulations. Anything could happen. While we might all agree that standard contract clauses are very desirable, if one includes too much in a standard contract clause there is a big danger that one will effectively increase the price of the premium. A lot of the features written into the standard contract clause may not be wanted by the ordinary person who is insuring. Let us take a simple case. Let us assume that I live in a flood prone area and my neighbour lives up on a hill and there is a standard clause in insurance policies which provides for flood insurance. If that is a standard clause, the fellow on the hill will not be interested in having his premium inflated for that reason. He will have to go along to the insurance company and ask for a special exclusion and try to negotiate a reduction in his premium. I admit that that is the sort of problem that could arise from a well- intentioned standard contract clause.

People do not want a whole lot of technical information. I am concerned that this Bill will result in a tremendous amount of highly technical information being put on the standard insurance contract form and will be gobbledegook to the ordinary policy holder. The ordinary policy holder wants the extent of his coverage written in simple terms so that he knows whether he can claim against a broken window, malicious damage to property in his house and so on. This is not difficult. But, as I have seen in company law legislation and many other areas, once one starts getting technical one finds that the understanding of the ordinary person tends to diminish. How many stockholders of companies understand a present day balance sheet? If it were not for the directors' reports, which in fairly simple terms outline whether they have made a profit or a loss or whether they are paying a dividend, et cetera, they would not have a clue. I can see the same situation occurring in insurance law. We are trying to complicate the matter for the ordinary policy holder whom we are trying to protect. So often with legislation nowadays the intention is good but the delivery leaves a heck of a lot to be desired.

I think it is unfortunate that this Insurance Contracts Bill which is before us tonight is not 100 per cent complete or right. Representations are still being made and changes are still needed to overcome some of the problems. This Government, which is devoid of legislation, has brought this incomplete legislation before the House of Representatives and the Senate. It is reported that both Houses could be rising earlier than intended simply because not enough legislation is coming through. We are asked to consider, at the last minute, a new set of amendments which, quite frankly, the majority of the honourable senators on the Opposition benches certainly have not had time to consider. I think this is important.

I have just mentioned some of the problems that I have picked up relating to a few of the 59 amendments. If there is further capitulation I wonder what sort of Bill we will finish up with. I believe that no legislation is better than bad legislation. What we are certainly getting at present is bad legislation. While I admire the Government's intention of trying to get the methodology and wording of this legislation right, I believe that it is quite inappropriate. We are likely to get a Bill which will impose further costs on policy holders. We will see a whole lot of technical information on clauses. They will be highly technical and legalistic and when they are legalistic it means more money for those wicked lawyers. We will find a lot more documentation. This extra documentation will confuse the issues rather than clarify them.

What does this Bill try to do? It tries to reform substantially and modernise insurance contract law on a national basis-a lofty ideal. But the bulk of insurance is State insurance which effectively is not within that scope. Within the insurance industry there have been unfortunately a number of collapses. The most prominent firms are Palmdale Insurance Ltd and Bishopsgate Insurance Australia Ltd. Regulation in any industry may in certain circumstances be desirable but, in my view, this is not such a case, given the present wording of this Bill and the amendments that we are asked to agree to. This Bill cannot really be said to be a codification of existing law. Rather, it deals with only some aspects of the law and is therefore superimposed on to the existing law. The Commonwealth cannot legislate with respect to State insurance conducted solely within the limits of the State. I echo the hope of the present Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) that the State and Northern Territory Attorneys- General will agree to the application of Commonwealth legislation to intra-State and extra-State insurance activities.

I think it is unfortunate for Australians generally that we cannot have a uniform law relating to insurance. This is one of the problems we are facing at present. If we really get back to laws, the crux of the problem of the insurance industry in recent years can be sheeted home to two main areas. The first is the Insurance Act. The Insurance Commission has operated largely as a toothless tiger. In addition, until recently there has been no attempt to regulate brokerage operations within the industry. The main thrust of the Insurance Commissioner towards the general insurance industry has been that, firstly, the lodgment of returns appears to have been delayed in certain circumstances and, secondly, when those returns are received by the Commissioner the ability of his office to interpret the financial thrust of each of the companies seems to be delayed to such an extent that remedial action cannot be enforced at a suitable time. I submit that if the Government is sincere in its desire to stabilise the insurance industry for the benefit of the consumer it must be able to analyse and detect where these faults arise.

To its credit, the Government intends to take some steps in this regard, particularly in relation to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill. But we are told that there are a number of amendments. If the amendments are of the same order and have the same force as the amendments to the Insurance Contracts Bill, there will be a big capitulation. Where will the ordinary person finish up? It would have been desirable for us to have debated cognately the Insurance Contracts Bill and the Insurance Brokers Bill. But no; we were first going to look at the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill and it was withdrawn for further amendments. I am aware that amendments are needed to clauses 12 and 14 of that Bill. The Bill was submitted but it has now been withdrawn. I understand it will be listed for debate tomorrow. I presume that the Senate will be expected to discuss and analyse the impact of further amendments. If there are no amendments the Government will create problems for itself. If the Bill is submitted tomorrow we will not have the opportunity of analysing the impact of those amendments. Whilst the rhetoric is there the action is lacking. I think this is somewhat regrettable.

No one would deny that the law of insurance requires some clarification and simplification. But I am sure that this Bill does not seek to simplify. It simply seeks to impose a whole lot of technical jargon. My colleague, Senator Archer, referred to all the different sorts of fraud that could be perpetrated. Yet, in most circumstances, the insurance industry had to honour a contract. What sort of legal position will a small policy holder find himself in when, through no fault of his own, he gets involved with a fellow who knocks at the door and presents what he thinks is a good policy. It could be written in South Africa or South America. The fellow does not have to be told this. The company may not even need to have a representative in the State in which the policy holder resides. That is not much help to the ordinary person. We need clarification. We need the Bill to be simple. We need a Bill to protect the ordinary policy holders. I do not know whether the Bill went to the back bench members of Caucus. I fail to see how ordinary Labor members could accept all these amendments. It surprises me.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to take it on the run as well.

—As Senator Hill said, maybe they have to take it on the run. In taking it on the run there are dangers, some of which I am trying to clarify tonight. But I think it is clear that rapidly changing technology, not only in the insurance industry but also in commerce has been required to adapt to changes. But it is not enough on its own to clarify the law of insurance to clear up issues regarding policy wording and contracts for the benefit of insurers. The whole financial structure of the industry must be streamlined in order that people's interests are protected at all times and that company collapses are minimised. The main concern of the insurance industry and the Government should be financial stability so that, as I mentioned, the client is protected at all times and is not faced with the prospect of his policy being worthless.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that some honourable senators may wonder why I have mentioned these things when the points that I am raising should have come from the Government side. I believe, as a representative of the people, that if Government members are not prepared to speak up somebody has to do so. It is often said that I have a certain sympathy with the business element. Whilst this may be so I have a duty to protect the ordinary small policy holder from what has been imposed upon him by the very representatives who should not be putting forward this sort of legislation.

While one may applaud the intentions of the Attorney-General in these matters- it sounds very nice to have a standard contract clause and a standard insurance from, which we believe could be beneficial-I do not think the Government should rest on its laurels. Unfortunately for many in the community, it has backpedalled. For example, I believe there should be, in addition to the annual returns submitted by companies to the Commissioner, provision for quarterly returns by companies, which would be easy to analyse and would allow the Insurance Commissioner to see the financial breakdown, if that is the case, which the company is following, or which must inevitably result.

Quarterly returns would not make it difficult for the Insurance Commissioner to assess the health of a company and, in so doing, the collapse of such firms as Bishopsgate would be avoided. The collapse of the Bishopsgate Insurance Company illustrates in a very graphic manner the failure of the Commissioner's office and the disastrous economic consequences for policy holders. While it may be seen to be desirable to introduce a number of measures to bring the Insurance Act and the insurance industry a little more up to date and to streamline it, the Government has gone about it in a haphazard, offhand manner. It circulated 59 amendments last week and further amendments today, before we have had time to consider this matter. That illustrates the problems the insurance industry faces .

Let us look at some statistics. We know that this Bill is largely the result of recommendations by the Law Reform Commission. There has been widespread dissatisfaction with contracts by insured people. But when the matters were put to the test, how many claims were rejected? About 2 per cent. Of the claims that have been rejected, 78 per cent were rejected because the policy document did not cover the item in dispute. A standard form of insurance would not necessarily overcome that sort of problem. What is needed is clarity or simplicity of wording. We will not get that from this Bill, which will require highly technical, verbose language in particular forms. I am afraid of what could happen in an area which has many different interpretations, or in circumstances in which fraud may or may not void a contract. I think this situation is most undesirable, and I therefore call upon the Government to withdraw its Bill and draw up one that will be satisfactory for the needs of a modern industry, and to keep it up to date.

One of the problems in the insurance industry has been that, with regard to the trade practices legislation, the insurance companies panicked. They withdrew standard clauses, standard ideas. Then we had the advent of overseas insurance companies in the Australian market. The Insurance Company of North America ( Australia) Ltd was one company which came in with the intention of skimming the cream off the industry and cutting premiums disastrously. It had very little structure with regard to servicing the small domestic policy holders. Unfortunately, a price war ensued. The short term result was some discounted premiums to policy holders. The long term result, I believe, in opening up this worldwide competition, which essentially skimmed the cream off the market, has been quite disastrous for the insurance industry. I hope the Government can learn from this situation, and that before it allows the entry of foreign banks into Australia it considers the ramifications that the entry of foreign-owned insurance companies has had on the Australian scene today. The long term ramifications, I believe, will be quite disastrous for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by congratulating the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), not so much on the Insurance Contracts Bill 1983, but because he has made a genuine attempt to reach a degree of consensus between the conflicting demands on the insurers and the insured. We will probably be debating whether or not he has been successful for the rest of this evening. There are a number of areas where it is quite obvious that he has had to come down on one side or the other, indicating that consensus has not been achieved. I think it is fair to say that there has been a high degree of consultation. Certainly over the last few days it has been at a rate of knots, as the two previous speakers, Senator Watson and Senator Archer, have indicated. We have all been taking amendments on the run. Not only have amendments been put forward in voluminous quantities, but amendments have been made to the amendments. They are not necessarily a bad thing, because it is an indication of the willingness of the Government, through the Attorney-General, to consider further endeavours by the insurance industry or the consumers to resolve the problems that have come about as a result of the first attempt at the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that we had a delay in the debate has been helpful and, having thrown a bouquet, I will now throw a brickbat. I was disappointed that the Attorney- General wanted to rush through this legislation. It has certainly become evident from my point of view, and obviously from the point of view of the speakers on behalf of the Opposition, that we have needed practically every minute we have had in the intervening few says to catch up not only with the amendments that are perceived to be necessary by the Attorney-General and his officers, but also with the views of the industry representatives, the consumers on those amendments. They very definitely did not have time to put those views to us prior to the break to give us time to consider this legislation and its amendments.

When we look at this Bill we recognise that it is a dramatic change in the Government's handling of the insurance industry. It is an industry in transition . It is an industry trying to take into account the shrinking world in which it exists and the fact that it has to communicate very quickly around that shrinking world. It is helped by modern technology, which in itself, of course, is quite a barrier to the development of an understanding of the changes that are necessary in that insurance world. The changing risks and the changing responsibilities are there for both the insurers and the insured. I think that both the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report and the Attorney-General have recognised that these changing risks and changing responsibilities on both sides need to be taken on board in considering appropriate legislation. The reforms were, in my opinion, absolutely necessary and overdue. I therefore do not have any quarrel with the endeavours to get the Bill up and running, and to get the amendments through, even on the run, as we are handling them tonight, because there is an urgent need for the insurance industry-as well as the consumer-to be able to stablise its position and to know where it is going.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are considering the Insurance Contracts Bill 1983 , a Bill which, in the normal course of events, would be considered by most people to be a rather dull, uninteresting and unexciting piece of legislation because it deals with a great number of clauses, contracts and machinery items which will completely change the insurance industry. Most people see the insurance industry as being people in large buildings in main streets, where many very complicated things take place but which do not have much relevance to the millions of people outside. In fact, this piece of legislation will have a great impact on millions of Australians because it redresses the imbalance between the insurer and the insured. It sets out, in accordance with recommendations made by the Australian Law Reform Commission, to tilt the scales the other way, to ensure that the consumer of insurance gets a fair go. By that I do not mean to imply that all insurance companies have been harsh in their treatment of insured people, but, because of the way the legislation has been framed in the past, the opportunity has been present for some unscrupulous insurance companies to take advantage of that legislation and to give insured people a raw deal.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will change that. I am delighted to say that, in the main, the changes which will be made have the support of the insurance industry. I do not say that it was done willingly. I am certainly not suggesting that it was done without some trepidation because of the potential impact on the industry. The industry has been willing to consult with the Minister concerned, the Attorney- General. It has been willing to concede that there was a need to redress the imbalance. It has been willing to accept a number of changes to the principles of insurance as well as a number of amendments that have been put forward by the representatives of the consumer organisations and the Law Council of Australia to ensure that this legislation will work, as far as practicable, and will have the desired effect on the insurance industry and all those who have to take out insurance policies.

Let me repeat, if I may, a comment that I made before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, which was that the Attorney-General is to be congratulated for the Bill and particularly for the amendments that have flowed on from discussion once the Bill's import was recognised-some of the problem areas needed to be redressed-and following that consultation, for his acceptance of proposals from a wide variety of sources, including other political parties, to modify the legislation so that it would work for the industry as well as for the insurance consumers.

The industry is in a state of massive transition. It is dealing with new technology. That in itself is not easy for industry. It has had to recognise that new technology has to be taken on board to make each of the insurance companies more and more competitive. That has caused massive retrenchments in the industry which, when one knows and deals with the individuals responsible for those decisions, must have been a very difficult time for the people in the industry, not the least, of course, for those employees who were retrenched as a result of the introduction of new technology. The arrival of new technology should have brought about fairly dramatic reductions in insurance premiums. That has come about in some areas but, in my view, is not sufficient to meet the demands of people who have to make that crunch decision as to whether or not they will insure. That is not just as individuals but as corporate bodies also. Obviously, the lower the cost of handling insurance policies, the lower the premium can be in a competitive market and the more people will be able to insure those things that may be at risk. That is a desirable goal but it is one which may be in conflict with some of the things that this legislation sets out to achieve because, in fact, in redressing some of the imbalances, the insurers will be at higher risk. That means quite simply that increased premiums will be charged to consumers, to cater for that increased risk. The insurance companies, recognising that, have said nevertheless that they are willing to live with this legislation, that they are willing to try it. It is to be hoped that, following a period of trial, the Minister and the Government will be willing to accept recommended modifications to the legislation as and when those modifications are required.

I think that it needs to be recognised that the Bill is based on the Australian Law Reform Commission report which made it quite clear that there is an urgent need for reform and rearrangements within the insurance industry. In particular, there needs to be a redress of the power imbalance between the insurers and the insured. This Bill certainly sets out to achieve that redress of the power in balance. It gives those who are insured much greater powers vis-a-vis the insurance companies. I expect this Government and any future Government to recognise that this Bill is only the first of a number of reforms that are necessary in this area. The insurance contracts with which this Bill deals are probably an appropriate first step. But a number of discrepancies still have to be addressed. One which we will be looking at shortly in this parliamentary session, it is to be hoped, is the insurance agents and brokers legislation dealing with the intermediaries between the insurance companies and the insured.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will we have 60 amendments to that?

—We may indeed have a number of amendments to that legislation as well, because that is probably the way major reform legislation should be handled. It should be brought down as proposed legislation but subject to a number of amendments once the concerns of the industry people and those who are affected are taken into account.
—After a reasonable time for consideration of the amendments.

—As Senator Hill says, it is most important that we, the legislators-not only the Government but also the legislators on both sides of this Parliament-have the time to consult with the representatives of all of the interested groups to ensure that the legislation goes through in a proper and workable form and is not just raced through with only one person being convinced that it will work, that person being the Minister at the table.

SPEECH.PARA: Other areas need to be looked at-as I said, it is to be hoped that this will follow-such as reinsurance because of the discrepancies that flow from this legislation between the requirements of Australian insurance companies and the ways that off-shore reinsurers operate and the provisions that they may or may not accept in this legislation. Another vital area which needs to be looked at by the Government and this Parliament is the provisions for ensuring the solvency of insurers, the solvency of those insurance companies in whom we place our trust each time we take out an insurance policy. I am sure that the Government is conscious of the fact that this legislation will probably bring about changes in both the size and the composition of the insurance market. There may be major changes in the number of companies and the size of companies that exist, in the Australian control and ownership of those companies, and in the very complex area of competition between State government insurance offices and private insurance companies. These are matters that need to be addressed and are virtually ignored by this piece of legislation.

It also needs to be borne in mind that insurance companies are responsible not only for providing insurance cover. They are amongst Australia's biggest investors, and they need a degree of regulation, along with the banks, building societies, friendly societies, credit unions and many other institutions involved in the financial markets, to ensure that they do not get an inordinate degree of control over the financial system and have an impact on this nation's economy which could be to our detriment.

There are a number of quite logical reforms in this Bill. The provision for the use of standard contracts is established by law for the first time. That is a very desirable achievement, because it means that people do not have to read through every insurance policy to ensure that there is not a missing clause or to ensure that there is not something else in it that no other insurance company includes which provides for an exclusion for their particular policy. I believe that the standard contracts approach is supported by the industry. It is probably something that had to be legislated for, because it would have taken decades for the industry to arrive at that point of agreement, simply because of the tremendous pressures on the various companies around Australia from their proprietors overseas. The other major reform in the legislation is that there is a degree of consumer protection which has never been seen in insurance legislation in this country.

There have been a number of problems associated with the creation and the development of this Bill. At one stage it was suggested that to help in the interpretation of the Bill we should go behind the Bill to the Australian Law Reform Commission report No. 20 to get the Commission's meaning of the words which were included in the legislation. That is not to be part of the Bill, as the Government has agreed to an amendment removing that provision. I would have envisaged that that would have resulted in very costly and lengthy litigation and argument, because much of the current legislation, as a result of the acceptance of alternatives and amendments, will be quite different from the draft legislation which was included in the Law Reform Commission's report. In any case, the Acts Interpretation Act probably makes that provision unnecessary, as where appropriate the power is there in existing legislation to use that method of interpreting the Bill.

One of the matters that needs to be looked at is the concept of the 'reasonable man'. I believe that the Government has accepted the view that the clause which provides that what a person in the insured's circumstances would reasonably be expected to know that an insurer would regard as relevant, left to a very subjective judgement the interpretation of what a person should know. There is case law which interprets what a reasonable man should be expected to know. That has now been included in the amendments to the Bill, and I believe that it is a much more acceptable approach but, nevertheless, a very contentious approach to this kind of legislation and an approach that is difficult to interpret; but at least there is case law on which interpretation can be based on the reasonable man principle. The clause to which I have just referred would have, in fact, words something along the lines of what a reasonable person could reasonably be expected to know an insurer would regard as relevant. That will be easier to adapt in this kind of legislation.

There is a cause of great concern both within the insurance industry and within honourable senators on this side of the Senate. That is that there is no inclusion of State government insurance offices in this legislation. I am willing to accept that it is not constitutionally possible for this Parliament to legislate for State government insurance offices. They have been so established that they escape any legislative provisions of this Parliament. Nevertheless, it places private insurance companies at a distinct disadvantage in competing in the areas in which they compete with State government insurance offices. I would have hoped that it would have been possible, before this legislation was introduced, for the Government to have been able to announce that the State governments had accepted the principles contained in this legislation and had agreed to legislate uniformly along the lines of this legislation to remove the advantage that will flow on to State government insurance offices as a result of this legislation being passed for all private insurance companies throughout Australia at stage one-that is, from the proclamation of this Bill-and not for State government insurance offices at the same time. It may well be that the Attorney-General and the Government will be able to persuade State governments to legislate uniformly along these lines, but it will leave that advantage over a period for State government offices, even given that the State governments are all willing to legislate along similar lines.

I ask the Attorney-General to give an assurance in his reply to the debate that there will be a continuing endeavour on the part of this Government to have State governments cover State government insurance offices along lines that are identical to the way in which private insurance offices have had to be covered and their consumers given the protection of this legislation.

The Government, insurance companies, the consumers and parliamentarians who have looked at this legislation have all had difficulty with two clauses, clauses 32 and 56, which deal with fraudulent misrepresentation by a person who is insured. The provisions seem, at first glance, to be impractical. There is the use of the terms that the court may disregard the avoidance of a contract for fraudulent misrepresentation or fraudulent non-disclosure if it would be harsh and unfair. Harsh and unfair to whom? Presumably, to the insured, but it may just as easily be interpreted to mean harsh and unfair to the insurer.

But what flows on from that provision is that if we open the doors to a little bit of fraudulent misrepresentation or fraudulent non-disclosure, are we not opening them to deliberate fraud and making it legal under this legislation? It is certainly an innovative concept to be introduced into legislation of this type. It throws the balance very much in favour of the insured. I guess that the reasoning is quite sound: Where a person makes a misrepresentation which does not affect the total insurance coverage he or she should not lose the total insurance and the total claim on such insurance as a result of having made a minor misrepresentation, even though it be fraudulent. That is probably the principle behind the proposal. I am not suggesting that that is a good principle , but if we want to push the balance back towards the consumer and away from the insurance companies one way of doing so is to say: 'We are not prepared to let the insurance companies be judge and jury of what is fraudulent misrepresentation. We will leave it to the courts to make that decision'. It does leave it to the courts to determine whether it is harsh and unfair and, therefore, whether they are willing to allow a little fraudulent misrepresentation or fraudulent non-disclosure. But I repeat: I believe it lets a little water escape from the dam and one finger may not be enough to stop the flow. Once we start to make fraudulent misrepresentation and fraudulent non- disclosure legally acceptable at any level we may not be able to stop the flood. This situation needs to be kept under the microscope and I would expect the insurance industry, the Law Reform Commission and any others interested in justice and in ensuring that outright cheats do not get away with it to come back to the Government if it looks like getting out of hand, because in the end we, the rest of the insured people of Australia, the 99 per cent who do not fraudulently misrepresent, will pay the additional premium if these people open the flood gates.

There are some amendments to be moved by the Opposition, some of which the Australian Democrats will be supporting. We will deal with those as we get to them. I raise one other point. Although in general the Australian Democrats support the thrust of this Bill, in the main because it moves the balance towards the consumer, towards those people who take out insurance policies in innocence expecting to be protected by an insurance company which until now has been the party against which the action is taken and the judge and jury taking a decision on that action, and because it gives the insured a better go in insurance, I believe it is important in debating this Bill to recognise that it will be an expensive change. The administrative costs of private insurance companies will be increased as a result, and that will flow on to consumers. That will result in increased premiums. It is impossible to calculate the amount , but we need to know that, as we pass this Bill, we are passing a Bill which will increase the cost of insurance but which will at the same time increase the certainty under which every person and every corporate body takes out that insurance.
