SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise again during the adjournment debate, as I have done on a number of occasions over the last few years, to address a continuing problem concerning Kenneth Dax, the naval cadet who was killed aboard HMAS Tobruk. I wish to refer to two items only tonight. One is a letter which the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) circulated to a number of honourable senators in response to issues which have been raised recently on this matter. That letter contains the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure you that Mr and Mrs Dax have been informed of all relevant facts. Following the accident, the Deputy Chief of Naval Staff personally wrote explaining the circumstances of Kenneth's death. Senior Naval Officers also visited the family and, at Mrs Dax's request, copies of official reports were provided. While a misunderstanding about the provision of these reports did occur, I do not believe that any material facts about the accident were withheld from Mr and Mrs Dax.
I would have thought that, by now, the facts of the matter have been sufficiently detailed and made sufficiently clear that a letter of that kind would not have been written.

I wish simply to make five comments in relation to that paragraph. Firstly I deal with the statement that the parents have been informed of all relevant facts and that the Deputy Chief of Naval Staff personally wrote explaining the circumstances. It has been established beyond question that explanations received during the first 12 months were woefully inadequate and evaded the truth on a number of occasions. I would have thought that that matter has now been sufficiently detailed as to warrant the type of comment that was made in that letter not being repeated. Secondly, I deal with the statement that senior naval officers also visited the family to answer their questions. I think it has also been clearly established that, while the officers who visited Mr and Mrs Dax were sympathetic-the parents have stated that publicly on a number of occasions-those naval officers were not able to answer any questions. It was only after the persistence of Mr and Mrs Dax over a number of months that their questions were forwarded to Canberra; hence the whole issue moved into the public arena.

Thirdly, there is the comment that copies of official reports of the incident were provided. That seems to suggest that only some mild problems were involved. Anybody who knows anything about this matter would know that this required a number of official representations over 11 months before a review of the report was obtained. That was 12 months after the release of the report. Fourthly, there is the statement that these were essentially technical reports. On 26 August 1982 the Deputy Chief of Naval Staff told Mr and Mrs Dax that he would not release the review and that it was too technical for them to understand. In other words, the statement contained in the Minister's letter is not correct.

Fifthly, the point has been made that no material facts were withheld. Undoubtedly the parents have suffered an enormous amount of added anguish and distress over the last 2 1/2 years because of the reluctance and the slowness of the Department of Defence to tell the whole story of what has occurred. That fact has been clearly established in a report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts to this chamber. I hope that the Minister's office and the person who obviously composed that letter for the Minister will look again at the copious records in this regard and not repeat those types of unsubstantiated propositions which have taken a lot of people's time to put to rest and have caused an enormous amount of anguish to the parents. I hope that in further letters the accurate representation of what has been established on the public record is adhered to so we do not have to go back to square one to correct the record yet again.

The second issue that I wish to raise with the Minister refers to another case that I believe shows how governments can act in this regard. I refer to the $300 ,000 compensation payment to the managers of the Sheraton Hotel as a result of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service raid. It was stated at the time that that was compensation for damages to the hotel and to its reputation as well as for the ordeal suffered by 15 staff members who had been bailed up at gunpoint. I have no idea how much it cost to repair the door but I cannot imagine that it would be a great deal. I do not know how much of that compensation was considered necessary to restore the reputation of the hotel. But in whatever way one looks at it, the amount left over for the 15 staff members must be in the order of $10,000.

Let us look at the alacrity with which the Government moved in this regard. Compensation was paid to each individual who suffered that anguish, which in many ways may have been terrifying at the time but was soon over and, doubtless, left those employees with a very good story to recount at dinner parties and the like. Presumably no permanent damage was suffered by those employees. On the other hand, if we look at the parents of Kenneth Dax, who so far have been offered $3,500 after 2 1/2 years battle and we compare those issues we discover that there is an enormous discrepancy in the way in which the Government has opted to treat compensation for individual Australian citizens.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) has said that there are likely to be changes to the law. They have not appeared. He has said that adequate compensation will be provided. That has not occurred. What has occurred since that last offer was made public on the record is nil. How much longer does the Government intend that this issue drag on before justice is done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes tonight, following the earlier debate, to talk about the crime of arson. Arson now occurs world-wide on a very massive scale. The Insurance Council of Australia suggests that the incidence of arson, mostly occurring without convictions or without the offenders even being charged, has reached the stage where it amounts to in the order of $820m a year and, of course, it is growing at a very rapid rate. I have had a considerably long term interest in the matter of arson. I have been involved with insurance people over many years where this had been a fact of life, both in the selling of insurance and in the handling of claims. The insurance industry is very concerned that Australia is still without legislation of any nature designed to combat arson and without any assistance to provide the necessary courses and instruction on how to stamp it out. We are in a society where great scorn is poured on insurers who query or contest claims where arson is suspected or probable. Certainly, the almost total absence of convictions for the crime of arson must and does act as a spur for those who contemplate burning something down illegally for personal gain. However, the present predicament in which the insurance industry and the community are heavily involved because of the great losses borne by insurers is forcing fire protection premiums up. This is what we are dealing with in the existing legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The private sector is in very serious trouble as a result of the way in which arson has got completely out of hand. The annual report for 1982-83 of the Insurance Commissioner shows that for the private sector direct underwriters there was a loss of $430m for the year ended 31 December 1982, $429m was recorded for the year ended 31 December 1981 and it was $227m for the year before that. The accumulated deficit over three years is $1,086m. The deficit for reinsurers deteriorated to $81m and the public sector deficit deteriorated to $325m in 1982 from $123m in 1981. That is the nature of the losses now occasioned in insurance which are very largely due to the enormous incidence of arson. Total premiums, according to the same report, for fire and householders and house owners insurance amount to $1,182m, say $1,200m. I am advised by the insurance industry that those costs double the insurance premiums to every insurer in those classes in Australia. If it is not worth doing something about trying to halve the insurance premiums instead of making all sorts of confectionary fiddles to the insurance legislation of the sort we have been debating tonight I do not know what is.

I have been in close touch with Miss Jane Evans of the Melbourne office of the Insurance Council of Australia, who has been waging the Council's campaign to bring arson under control for several years. As a result of her work, together with the efforts of State fire brigades and police, we are now seeing what can be done to slow down the snowballing effect on the community and the Government generally. The first national conference on arson was staged by the Australian Institute of Criminology and the ICA in mid-1983. As a follow-up a national standing committee on arson is currently being formed. The office bearers have not yet been elected but the membership to date is building up as follows: Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia, representatives of the fire authorities executive committee, the Chairman of the Insurance Resource Committee on Arson, the Institute of Loss Adjusters, the Association of Risk and Insurance Managers of Australia, specialist investigators and the insurance solicitors. It is anticipated that nominations will be received in due course from the New South Wales Standing Committee on Arson and the Department of Defence.

Whilst this is excellent progress from a standing start last year, I for one expect that all States and Territories will add their presence so that this new and important committee can be as solid as necessary to handle the rotten problem of arson. I have discussed the matter with the Premier of my State, who says that the State will establish a standing committee on arson in the very near future but that already arson investigation courses are being conducted at the Police Academy. They are attended by officers of the State fire service, the Telecom Australia investigation section, insurance loss assessors, representatives of the Victorian metropolitan and country fire services, Victorian police and Australian Federal Police and the New South Wales insurance industry. I quote from a summary of the national conference as provided in a background paper for a meeting of Ministers on 9 March 1984. The summary states:
SUMMARY

Resolutions of the national conference on arson are still under examination by fire authorities, and a general viewpoint has not yet emerged. It is likely that considerable further investigation will be required before soundly based recommendations can be placed before Ministers. However, there is general support for a national approach to the problem of arson, augmented by effective liaison and co-operation between police and fire authorities at State/ Territory level.
The attention of Ministers is particularly directed to the following resolutions passed at the national conference on arson.
Resolution 1.
That a national body be established and funded by the Federal Government to be the co-ordinating body for a federally funded counter-arson plan.
Resolution 2.

The national arson seminar calls on Federal and State governments to acknowledge the enormous costs to the Australian community and economy of deliberately lit fires and asks that the Federal Government accepts its responsibility for this national problem in at least the following ways:

(A) The Australian Bureau of Statistics to be responsible for producing meaningful fire statistics from information supplied by State fire authorities through the national fire incident reporting scheme.

(B) The resources of the A.C.T. Fire Brigade and the Federal Police be made available for the establishment of a national fire investigation course based in Canberra and open to fire brigade, police, insurance and other component bodies.
(C) To fund the national body referred to in Resolution 1.
(D) To fund the research into forensic technology.
Resolution 4.
That a recognised training facility for fire investigators, insurers and self- insurers, be established.
Resolution 6.

That Ministers for police and emergency services in each State be asked to reject proposed moves by the Federal Attorney-General to ease the non-disclosure and misrepresentation factors in favour of the policyholders in insurance contracts.
Resolution 11.
That Federal and State legislators recognise the need to formulate uniform, effective laws and regulations throughout Australia, relating to arson.

Since the national conference the national standing committee has met to give further consideration to the conference resolutions, but no new initiatives have yet been announced. I urge all in responsibility to take a big interest in combating this crime by giving the new national standing committee on arson their full backing and support to wipe out arson in Australia. I stress the overdue need for legislation relating to insurance. The need is to attack criminal arson, defend honest insurers and halve the fire insurance premiums now being paid. I believe that such legislation should be beneficial to Australia. Certainly it is necessary and attention to criminal arson is long overdue. I urge that there be an appropriate conference of State and Federal authorities, insurance and other interests specifically to consider the legislative procedures that may be desirable and that may promote awareness and training in giving attention to and defeating this horrible crime. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a one-page document, which I copied from an American publication, setting out the details of arson reporting immunity laws.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ARSON REPORTING IMMUNITY LAWS
Background

A key element in detection and prosecution of arson is the exchange of information between insurance companies and public officials. One of the problems insurers have faced in sharing information with law enforcement authorities has been the threat of civil suit. Arson reporting immunity laws are designed to protect insurance companies from suits when they share arson-related information with law enforcement officials. By encouraging the exchange of information, such laws increase the number of fraud arson claims denied and increase the number of arrests and convictions.

In 1976, the Ohio Legislature enacted what is believed to be the first law granting insurance companies immunity from suit when they share arson-related information with law enforcement officials. In 1977, the alliance of American insurers drafted model legislation entitled, 'Arson Reporting-Immunity Bill'. This model is supported by the National Association of Independent Insurers, the American Insurance Association, and other members of the Insurance Committee for Arson Control.

The major purpose of this model law is to increase the flow of vital investigative information between insurance companies and law enforcement agencies. The law requires insurers to inform the state fire marshal or other authorized persons of fires that appear to be suspicious in origin. It permits insurers and arson investigators to exchange information developed during their separate investigations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What controls presently exist to control the movement of capital into and out of the country.

(2) Does the Government have plans to implement more effective controls over the movement of capital between Australia and other countries in view of the large capital movements from Australia prior to the last Federal election; if so , what is the Government's intention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 9 December 1983 I announced the Government's decision-with effect from 12 December-to allow the value of the Australian dollar to float and to abolish a major part of the existing exchange controls. For the time being, exchange control approval is still required for the bulk of overseas transactions; this is to take account of the Government's tax screening and foreign investment policies. However, approval is normally readily given. Exchange control restrictions have been retained on interest bearing investments in Australia by governments, government agencies and foreign banks.

(2) The new arrangements I announced on 9 December 1983 will allow the exchange rate to respond more readily to market forces and should mean that external transactions will no longer be a major aberrant factor in determining monetary growth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Treasurer given instructions that the Northern Territory be included in the review of State relativities being undertaken in the lead up to the termination of the State tax sharing arrangements in June 1985.

(2) Does the Treasurer realise that a change in the funding arrangements will cost the Northern Territory millions of dollars and will put a brake on the rapid growth that has occurred in the Territory since self government.
(3) Will the Treasurer move to ensure no change is made to the funding arrangements, as set out in the memorandum of understanding for the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Terms of reference for a review of the distribution of tax sharing grants were transmitted to the Commonwealth Grants Commission in a letter of 10 February 1984 from the Special Minister of State. To facilitate consideration of the tax sharing arrangements which should apply after 1984-85, the Commission has been asked to make its assessments and to report on alternative bases in certain areas. One example of this is the request to the Commission to report on both a distribution of tax sharing grants among the States only and on a distribution of the grants among the States and the Northern Territory with the latter being treated on the same basis as the States.

(2) The Commission has been asked to base its assessments on the application of the principle that the respective tax sharing grants to which the States, and the Territory, are entitled should enable them to provide, without having to impose taxes and charges at levels appreciably different from the levels imposed in the other States, and the Territory's government services at standards not appreciably different from the standards provided by the other States and the Territory. (3) The Memorandum of Understanding states that 'The arrangements may have to be changed from time to time in the light of changing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States'. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much and in what form is statistical information kept on the degree of foreign ownership and control of the Australian private sector.

(2) Will the Treasurer provide sufficient funds for the Australian Bureau of Statistics to conduct a comprehensive study of the degree of such ownership and control in the private sector in Australia.
(3) Can the Treasurer indicate the nature and extent of such problems if it is claimed that there are methodological problems involved in such a survey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Statistical information on the degree of foreign ownership and control of selected industries and activities in the private sector is available in publications issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Publications have been produced for the following industries and economic activities:
(a) Finance companies-1973 and 1976
(b) Registered financial corporations-1976
(c) General insurance-1972-73 and 1975-76
(d) Life insurance-1973 and 1976
(e) Tourist accommodation-1973-74
(f) Advertising agencies-1974-75
(g) Research and development-1976-77
(h) Mineral exploration-1975-76
(k) Mining and selected mineral processing industries-1981-82.

The range of data items included in these publications is determined by the availability of data from the relevant source collections. For example, the most recent publication, Foreign Ownership and Control of the Mining Industry and Selected Mineral Processing Industries, Australia, 1981-82 (Catalogue No. 5317.0 ) contains information on employment, wages and salaries, turnover, value added and fixed capital expenditure of mining and selected mineral processing establishments:
(a) apportioned to ownership by type and country of ownership, State of location and industry; and
(b) allocated to control by type and country of control, industry, State of location and degree of influence of largest foreign investor.

(2) A Foreign Participation Section has been established in the ABS and will progressively compile foreign ownership and control statistics for a wide range of industries and activities, including agriculture, mining, manufacturing, construction, retail trade, transport and finance industries. A review of users' requirements conducted prior to the re-establishment of the Section showed some support for a study of the private sector as a whole but it did not rate highly in users' priorities and there are no plans to conduct such a study in the near future.

(3) A comprehensive study of the degree of foreign ownership and control in the private sector in Australia would involve a number of conceptual and practical problems. On the conceptual level, there would be problems in determining how the degree of foreign ownership or control in one industry should be added to that for other industries in order to produce a figure for all industries combined. Different data items would give significantly different results when used as a measure across all industries. As a consequence it would probably be necessary to produce results using various measures and leave users to make their own judgments about the relative usefulness of the different figures. Practical problems would also arise as much of the data required for the various measures would not be available from existing ABS collections, or would only be available in respect of different reference periods. A comprehensive study covering all industries in the private sector would therefore involve additional data collection, with substantial associated costs and increased respondent burden.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Treasurer aware that whereas in 1959 there were only two foreign owned advertising agencies, today some 20 foreign owned advertising agencies control 85 per cent of all Australian advertising.
(2) What action does the Treasurer intend to take to rectify this lamentable state of affairs in such a key industry.

(3) Is the Government prepared to use its market power to increase the proportion of Australian ownership and control of the advertising industry in this country, since the Government through public authorities and statutory authorities is the largest advertiser in the country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys of foreign ownership and control covering accredited advertising agencies showed that in 1974-75 foreign ownership, measured in terms of turnover, was 43 per cent while foreign control accounted for 51 per cent of total turnover. While there are no more recent official statistics available, data available from advertising industry journals and industry sources indicate that in 1982 the top 20 advertising agencies with foreign ownership of 15 per cent or more accounted for about 65 per cent of the total billings of the top 150 agencies in Australia. Foreign controlled agencies amongst these top 20 agencies accounted for about 48 per cent of the total billings of the top 150 agencies.

(2) Given the high level of foreign ownership and control in the advertising industry, all foreign investment proposals are closely examined on a case-by- case basis under the Government's foreign investment policy.

(3) I am informed that the selection of advertising agencies for Commonwealth business follows the principle, as with the purchase of other similar services, of seeking the most efficient and effective service. There is, therefore, no policy in existence, or contemplated, to exclude agencies with foreign ownership interests from performing Commonwealth advertising. However, I am also informed that, as far as is practicable, the Australian Government Advertising Service ( AGAS)-which of course comes within the portfolio responsibilities of the Special Minister of State-now includes Australian-owned agencies, of adequate capacity and resources, in all panels of agencies invited to submit for government advertising business.

In practice, Australian-owned agencies are well represented in the agencies which are engaged by AGAS. The figures provided to me show that in 1982-83, 51 agencies participated in Commonwealth advertising and associated work arranged by AGAS. Of these, 31 were fully Australian-owned and 3 others had majority Australian ownership; these 34 predominantly Australian owned advertising agencies accounted for about 70 per cent of the total payments made in respect of all advertising and associated work arranged by AGAS. To date in 1983-84, 28 of the 41 agencies involved with AGAS work were fully Australian-owned and three had majority Australian ownership; these 28 agencies received about 76 per cent of the total payments so far recorded in 1983-84 as having been received by all agencies for services to the Commonwealth through AGAS.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Income Tax Concessions on Health Insurance

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 and 26 May 1983 (Hansard, pages 755 and 889 respectively) Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle addressed questions without notice to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerning the income tax rebate, now withdrawn , in respect of contributions for basic health and medical insurance. The questions were referred to the Treasurer who apologises for the delay in replying and has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's election health policy statement made it clear that the income tax rebate for basic health insurance premiums would be abolished in order to help finance the Medicare arrangement. I am unable to locate, however, any statement that would provide a basis for the honourable senator's suggestion that the Government gave a pre-election undertaking not to remove the rebate prior to the introduction of Medicare.

As to the second part of the honourable senator's questions, there is no immediate impact on families resulting from the removal of the rebate for health insurance contributions made in respect of the period 1 July, 1983 to 31 January , 1984, that is, the period prior to the introduction of Medicare, because the rebate for health insurance contributions is not reflected in the tax instalments deducted from the salaries or wages of employees.

The cost to families of denying the rebate for health insurance contributions in respect of the period 1 July, 1983 to 31 January, 1984 is put at about $333m. Of this amount, only the provisional tax component of about $55m, which is not payable before 31 March, 1984, will impact on revenue in 1983-84.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1984 (Hansard, pages 1018-19) Senator Missen asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the Film Australia program The Human Face of Russia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Australian Film Commission has advised that:

The 90-minute program The Human Face of Russia recently screened by the 10- network in Melbourne and Sydney, was based on material shot for a three-part series called The Russians which was made by Film Australia in 1977 and broadcast in 1979 by Channel 7.
The program forms part of Film Australia's continuing and highly successful Human Face series. The Human Faces of China, Japan and the Pacific are other programs in this series.

The Human Face series focuses on individuals, not systems or ideologies. It is designed to equate ordinary Australians with counterparts in other countries. The 90-minute format obviously imposes some constraints and does not permit for indepth coverage or analysis of a country as broad and diverse as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Indeed, the opening commentary in the film makes the point that there are 100 different ethnic groups and 100 different languages in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has also advised that he has not seen the film and that Australian and overseas distribution of this program is a matter for Film Australia and the Commission. Under sub-section 8 (1) of the Australian Film Commission Act 1975, the Minister may give directions to the Commission with respect to the exercise of its powers or the performance of its functions but shall not give such a direction with respect to a particular project.
